choices.text: Drug B is most efficacious
Drug A and C are equipotent
Drug B is more efficacious and less potent than drug A
Drug A and C are equiefficacious

questions.text: Log DRC of four drugs is shown in the given diagram. Which of the following statements is correct about these drugs?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Drug A and C are equiefficacious

  • In DRC, potency is assessed by looking at the location of the curve on the X-axis. Curves on the right side are less potent and on the left are more potent. And efficacy is assessed by the height of the curve on y-axis, higher the curve, more efficacious it is.
  • Drug B is most potent but least efficacious
  • Drug A and C are equi efficacious but Drug A is more potent than C.
  • Drug D is least potent and equi-efficacious to drug A and C.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man presented with a severe, electric pain over posterior tongue and pharynx. It starts suddenly, lasts 1-2 minutes and precipitated by swallowing. Which of the following medications is indicated at this time?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Carbamazepine

The clinical case is characteristic for glossopharyngeal neuralgia, which presents as a severe, shock-like pain, usually over the areas supplied by glossopharyngeal nerve. Treatment is similar to that of trigeminal neuralgia.

questions.text: A 56-year-old man presented with the sudden onset of a severe headache. He was awake, but feeling uncomfortable because of headache. His initial plain CT head was normal. Lumbar puncture was performed and CSF was shown below. What is the next step?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Digital Subtraction Angiography

The CSF is consistent with xanthochromia and hence the likely diagnosis is subarachnoid hemorrhage. The ideal next step will be to locate the aneurysm with angiographic techniques. Repeating CT head will have no additional diagnostic yield.

questions.text: Which of the following cancers and the Immunohistochemistry (IHC) marker is not correctly matched?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Factor VIII- rhabdomyosarcoma

Factor VIII is marker of angiosarcoma and myoD1 is for rhabdomyosarcoma.

choices.text: Increased survival time in host cells
Enhanced release of tumour suppressor gene products
Integration of viral RNA with host DNA

questions.text: Hepatitis B is associated with increased risk of liver cancer in patients because of?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. High rate of hepatocyte proliferation

High rate of hepatocyte proliferation leads to increased accumulation of genetic mutations leading to higher risk of cancer.

choices.text: T wave – Ventricular depolarization

questions.text: Which of the following electrocardiograph waveform is matched correctly to the cardiac cycle?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. PR interval - Atrial depolarization

 

The electrocardiogram waveforms are labelled alphabetically, beginning with the P wave, which represents atrial depolarization.

 

The QRS complex represents ventricular depolarization, and the ST-T-U complex (ST segment, T wave, and U wave) represents ventricular repolarization. The J point is the junction between the end of the QRS complex and the beginning of the ST segment. Atrial repolarization (STa and Ta – usually corresponds to the PR interval) is usually too low in amplitude to be detected, but it may become apparent in conditions such as acute pericarditis and atrial infarction.

questions.text: Mr. Smith, a 55-year-old male patient, has been diagnosed with laryngeal malignancy and is scheduled to undergo modified radical neck dissection (MRND). The surgery is being performed in a sitting position to provide the surgeon with better access to the operative field. The anaesthetic team has taken all necessary precautions to prevent any complications during the surgery. During the surgery, while ligating the internal jugular vein, the patient's end-tidal carbon dioxide (etCO2) dropped from 40 mmHg to 14 mmHg. The patient suddenly developed hypotension along with cardiac arrhythmia, and the surgical team immediately recognized the emergency situation. Which of the following is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Venous air embolism

There are 4 important events here:

  • Bleeding from Internal jugular vein (severed vein which can entrap air)
  • A drastic fall in etCO2
  • Hypotension
  • Neck surgery – requires head-up position which reduces blood pressure in neck veins

This most likely points to – Venous air embolism.

In sympathetic overactivity and carotid body stimulation, blood pressure will rise.

In vagal stimulation, a sudden drop in etCO2 is unlikely.

choices.text: Scalp, epicranium, endocranium and dura
Scalp, synchondral membrane, dura, arachnoid

questions.text: A 5-month-old girl was brought to the casualty with seizures. The paediatrician tries to do CSF sampling. What are the structures punctured by the paediatrician while piercing through anterior fontanelle?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Scalp, dura, arachnoid

The procedure of collecting CSF from the anterior fontanelle is called ventricular tapping. The various structures pierced are the scalp, dura, and arachnoid.

Fontanelle tap/Percutaneous ventricular puncture:

A fontanelle tap or percutaneous ventricular puncture is performed in infants without access to a VP shunt, who require urgent ventricular decompression and have an open anterior fontanelle. The infants' open fontanelle is directly punctured with a butterfly needle to enter the lateral ventricle to collect CSF samples or release the pressure or place a drain/catheter.

A 25-gauge butterfly needle is inserted through the anterolateral aspect of the anterior fontanelle (away from the midline, avoiding the superior sagittal sinus).

The image below shows the various fontanelles.

 

The scalp is a soft tissue that covers the calvaria of the skull. It consists of five layers (Mnemonic: SCALP). Below the scalp and the calvaria lie the meningeal layers, namely, pachymeninges [arachnoid + dura mater (P-AD)] and leptomeninges [arachnoid + pia mater (L-AP)]. One must reach the subarachnoid space below the arachnoid layer to collect or tap CSF. So, the layers pierced in the order are as follows:

  1. Skin
  2. Connective tissue (superficial fascia) with blood vessels and nerves
  3. Aponeurosis (galea aponeurotica) with occipitofrontalis muscle
  4. Loose areolar (subaponeurotic) tissue
  5. Pericranium
  6. Dura mater
  7. Arachnoid membrane

questions.text: Advanced bipolar energy sources can coagulate vessels directly of diameter?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Upto 7 mm

Surgeons have increasingly used advanced energy devices to facilitate dissection and to seal and divide blood vessels up to 7 mm in diameter.

  • There are three main types of advanced energy devices: bipolar electrosurgery, ultrasonic electrosurgery and combination device. 
  • Bipolar: New technology such as the LigaSure™ system (Medtronic) involves advanced bipolar technology that uses the body’s collagen and elastin to both seal and divide, allowing surgeons to reduce instrument handling when dissecting, ligating and grasping – a valuable asset particularly during laparoscopic surgery. The feedback-sensing technology incorporated in the instrument is designed to manage the energy delivery in a precise manner and results in automatic discontinuation of energy once the seal is complete.
  • Ultra-sonic: The harmonic scalpel is an instrument that uses ultrasound technology to cut tissues while simultaneously sealing them. It utilizes a hand-held ultrasound transducer and scalpel that is controlled by a hand switch or foot pedal. During use, the scalpel vibrates in the 20,000–50,000-Hz range and cuts through tissues, effecting haemostasis by sealing vessels and tissues by means of protein denaturation caused by vibration rather than heat (in a similar manner to whisking an egg white).

questions.text: A Female had a thorn prick 5 years ago. She presented with a slowly growing 2 × 2 cm verrucous lesion which on KOH mount showed the following image. Identify the condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. D.  Chromoblastomycosis

Chromoblastomycosis

  • Lesions are typically slow growing and polymorphic, such as verrucose (most common type), crusted, ulcerative and nodular or tumor like

Histopathological staining à

  • Sclerotic bodies: Brown thick-walled round cells (5–12 µm size) with multiple internal transverse septa.
  • Also called à Medlar bodies, Muriform cells, Golden-brown septate “copper pennies”.

choices.text: Reduced R-time, increased angle, increased MA, increased LY30
Prolonged R-time, decreased angle, decreased MA, decreased LY30
Prolonged R-time, increased angle, decreased MA, increased LY30
Reduced R-time, decreased angle, increased MA, decreased LY30

questions.text: A 65-year-old male with a history of atrial fibrillation and recent coronary artery bypass graft surgery presents with bleeding from the surgical wound site. Laboratory tests reveal a normal platelet count and coagulation panel. Thromboelastography (TEG) is ordered to assess the patient's clotting profile. Which of the following TEG tracings is most consistent with the patient's presentation?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Prolonged R-time, increased angle, decreased MA, increased LY30

Thromboelastography (TEG) is a viscoelastic test that provides a graphical representation of the clotting process. The TEG tracing consists of several parameters, including R-time (reaction time), angle, maximum amplitude (MA), and LY30 (lysis at 30 minutes).

The patient is on anticoagulation and anti-platelet drugs (the patient has a history of atrial fibrillation, which increases the risk of thromboembolic events and the need for anticoagulation therapy and a recent CABG) ...so, he is bleeding. Therefore, the correct answer is (C) which is indicative of delayed clot formation, reduced clot strength, and increased fibrinolysis, suggesting an impaired clotting profile and increased bleeding risk in this patient.

Option A is incorrect because it shows a reduced R-time, which is not consistent with increased bleeding risk. Option B is incorrect because it shows a prolonged R-time, decreased angle, and decreased MA, which are not consistent with increased clot formation. Option D is incorrect because it shows a reduced R-time, decreased angle, and increased MA, which are not consistent with increased bleeding risk.

questions.text: James is a 2-year-old boy who has been struggling with social interaction and communication. He doesn't make eye contact with others, doesn't respond to his name being called, and has delayed speech development. He is often fixated on certain objects or activities and gets upset when his routine is disrupted. What could be the possible diagnosis in this child?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Autism

The given scenario is a typical case of Autism.

Triad:

  • Impairment of social behaviour
  • Communication skills
  • Stereotypical & restrictive behavioural pattern

Screening tool:

M-CHAT (Modified Checklist for Autism in Toddlers) for 16-30 months of age.

questions.text: Match the following therapeutic methods used in the management of psoriasis with their possible side effects?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. 1-c, 2-b, 3-a, 4-d

Over 90% of cases of psoriasis are successfully treated with PUVA. Both acute (erythema, blistering) and chronic side effects are associated to it. Use of PUVA for an extended period of time is linked to non-melanoma skin cancer development (squamous cell cancers and basal cell cancer).

Cyclosporine is primarily linked to metabolic issues, a possible increased risk of malignancy, and renal impairment (decreased GFR). Due to its nephrotoxic effects, it is now uncommonly used for the maintenance of psoriasis.

Both acitretin and methotrexate are teratogenic.

Acitretin is linked to hyperlipidaemia and mucocutaneous side effects (mucositis) that are dose-dependent. Female patients should abstain from getting pregnant for three years after stopping acitretin treatment to prevent retinoid-induced embryopathy.

Acitretin is approved for use in treating the psoriasis cutaneous symptoms.

Methotrexate, has been used as an abortifacient and is used in the management of molar pregnancies. Methotrexate is also associated with hepatotoxicity.

 

Ref: Rooks textbook of dermatology, 9th Edition, page no. 35.31

choices.text: Metabolic alkalosis, aldosterone and angiotensin II
Respiratory acidosis, aldosterone and angiotensin II

questions.text:
A 32-year-old woman is suffering from common cold visited the hospital with complain of vomiting since three days and extreme weakness. Her examination and lab findings are as follow:

BP - 90/60mmHg

Pulse - 110/ min

RR - 10/min

Blood pH - 7.6

Plasma bicarbonate - 30mEq/L

What should be patient’s current acid-base status and hormone involved?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Metabolic alkalosis, aldosterone and angiotensin II

Options C and D are incorrect à The combination of the alkaline pH and elevated serum bicarbonate indicates metabolic alkalosis. So, options C and D are not correct.

  • The excessive vomiting caused volume contraction which leads to activation of RAAS (renin angiotensin aldosterone system).
  • Aldosterone stimulates the H+ ATPase in the alpha intercalated cells of the distal nephron, which in turn increases reabsorption of newly synthesized HCO3-.
  • Angiotensin II stimulates Na+ -H+ exchange in PCT. This leads to an increase in reabsorption of HCO3- that had been filtered by glomerulus. Both PCT and DCT increase plasma HCO3-.
  • Whereas ANP is released in response to volume overload, which stretches the atrial walls and not pH change.

questions.text: Identify the Diagram shown in the image below?
questions.solution:
Ans D. Sufficient component cause model

Sufficient-component cause model:

  • Rothman recognized that disease outcomes have multiple contributing determinants that may act together to produce a given instance of disease
  • Rothman defined a sufficient cause as ‘a complete causal mechanism’ that ‘inevitably produces disease.’ Consequently, a ‘sufficient cause’ is not a single factor, but a minimum set of factors and circumstances that, if present in a given individual, will produce the disease
  • According to this model, sufficient cause for an outcome is determined by a set of minimal conditions and events that inevitably produce the stated outcome. This implies that all of the minimal conditions or events are necessary for the outcome to occur. Each component cause is therefore a necessary part of the causal mechanism it contributes to; in other words, no one factor is stronger than any of the others. A specific component cause may play a role in one, two or more sufficient causes. A component which is present in all sufficient causes is known as a necessary cause.
  • In the figures given, for the given disease, A is the necessary cause as it is present in all the diagrams; and B, C, D, E, F, G, H are component causes.

questions.text: A 24-year-old male is brought to the psychiatry emergency department by his family members. They report that he has been muttering to himself, exhibiting suspicious behaviour, and believing that neighbours are conspiring against him by video recording him. He has not attended work for the last three months. Over the past month, he has become more withdrawn, speaking minimally, and has been observed standing in his room at the same place for hours. In the last two days, the patient has stopped speaking completely and has refused food and water. In the emergency department, the patient did not respond to any questions and stood as given in the image below for 30 minutes. What is the best next step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. IV lorazepam

The patient's symptoms – muttering to himself (hallucinatory behaviour), suspicion of conspiracy (suggestive of delusions), social withdrawal, and catatonic behaviour (speaking minimally, standing at the same place for hours) – are suggestive of schizophrenia.

The current symptoms (posturing, standing in the same posture for 30 min), refusal to eat or drink & mutism (not responding to any questions) are suggestive of catatonia. This is a medical emergency. In cases of catatonia, the best initial management is to treat the catatonic symptoms with IV lorazepam.

Option A. Risperidone is an atypical antipsychotic and can be used to treat schizophrenia. However, it would not be the best initial management for the catatonic symptoms.

Option C. Electroconvulsive therapy (ECT) can be effective in the management of catatonia. However, it is typically used for patients who do not respond to I.V. lorazepam.

Option D. Haloperidol is a typical antipsychotic, and can be used to treat schizophrenia. However, it is less favoured in comparison to atypical antipsychotics like risperidone. Furthermore, like risperidone, haloperidol would not be the best initial management for the catatonic symptoms.

In summary, the best next step in the management of this patient is to administer IV lorazepam to address the acute catatonic symptoms. Following this, the treatment of the underlying psychotic disorder with an appropriate antipsychotic medication, such as risperidone, can be initiated.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient presents to their primary care physician with a complaint of dysphagia. He reports that he experiences a sensation of food getting stuck in his throat when he eats. He also reports some mild chest discomfort with exertion. The patient has a history of Down syndrome and congenital heart disease. Which imaging modality is typically used to diagnose dysphagia lusoria?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Computed tomography angiography

Computed tomography angiogram (CTA) confirms the diagnosis of an aberrant right subclavian artery that is compressing the oesophagus, leading to his dysphagia, known as dysphagia lusoria.

An aberrant right subclavian artery is a congenital anomaly in which the right subclavian artery arises distal to the left subclavian artery and passes posterior to the oesophagus, causing compression and sometimes leading to dysphagia, stridor, or other symptoms.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy came with complaints of anaemia, weakness, with low weight to height ratio for his age profile. On examination, urine sample shows elevated level of orotic acid. Further study reveals low uridine monophosphate (UMP) synthase activity. What can be the best treatment to administer?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Uridine                   

  • Orotic Aciduria is a condition resulting from absence of one or both enzymes namely, OPRTase and OMP decarboxylase.
  • Clinical features- retarded growth, megaloblastic anaemia, crystals excretion causes urinary tract obstruction.
  • Due to loss of feedback inhibition, orotic acid production increases drastically.
  • The condition is treated by feeding cytidine or uridine, which may be converted to Uridine triphosphate (UTP) – act as feedback inhibition.

Incorrect answers:

False: Option A. Adenine and Option C. Hypoxanthine: Hypoxanthine, guanine, and adenine are purine bases, cannot be converted to pyrimidines.

False: Option D. Thymidine: Although thymidine is a pyrimidine base it cannot be converted to other pyrimidines.

choices.text: True positive fistula test indicates perilymph fistula
False positive fistula test indicates congenital syphilis
True negative fistula test indicates late stages of Meniere’s disease
False negative fistula test indicates dead labyrinth

questions.text: Identify the false statement from the following:
questions.solution:
Ans. C. True negative fistula test indicates late stages of Meniere’s disease

Labyrinthitis (complication of Chronic suppurative otitis media (CSOM)) can occur if disease spreads into inner ear. Bone of lateral semi-circular canal gets eroded by cholesteatoma and a perilymph fistula (circumscribed labyrinthitis) is formed. Fistula sign (Changing pressure in External auditory canal by pressing tragus or seigelisation causes vertigo) detects it’s presence. (False positive fistula sign – no fistula but test positive – is seen in congenital syphilis due to hypermobile stapes footplate and in few cases of late stage Meniere’s disease due to fibrous attachments between membranous labyrinth and footplate. It is called Hennebert sign). (False negative fistula sign – has fistula but test negative – dead labyrinth, cholesteatoma covering the fistula). If complete labyrinth gets involved but no pus formation, then it is diffuse serous labyrinthitis and if there is pus formation, then it is diffuse suppurative labyrinthitis.

Fitzgerald-hallpike bithermal caloric test is done to detect perilymph fistula (of only lateral semi-circular canal, not much useful if fistula is on other canals). Patient lies supine with head tilted to 30 degrees. EAC is irrigated with warm (44 degree Celsius) water and cold (30 degree Celsius) water. This causes vertigo and produces nystagmus in normal people and the direction of nystagmus will be as per COWS (Cold Opposite Warm Same), that means, cold water stimulation causes nystagmus to opposite side & warm water stimulation causes nystagmus to same side. This normal pattern is not seen in patients with perilymph fistula.

questions.text: Police officers found a completely burnt dead body of a person in a forest. They suspect that someone might have killed him and later burnt the dead body to avoid identification. Doctor while conducting the post-mortem, found a significant finding in the larynx as shown below. This is suggestive of?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Antemortem Burns

The image shows soot in trachea which is suggestive of antemortem burns.

questions.text: Rearrange the sequence of hand washing:
questions.solution:
Ans. D. a; c; d; b

Steps of hand rubbing and handwashing (WHO):

  • Hand rub  à step 1 to 7  à 20–40 seconds
  • Handwash à step 1 to 10  à 40–60 seconds

choices.text: Presence of an abnormal discharge and erythema of the vagina
Clue cells seen on vaginal saline preparation by light microscopy
Characteristic fishy odour release with addition of potassium hydroxide to vaginal secretions

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT one of the three clinical diagnostic criteria for bacterial vaginosis described by Amsel?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Presence of an abnormal discharge and erythema of the vagina

 

  • Bacterial Vaginosis is diagnosed by Amsel Criteria
  • Amsel Criteria is 3 out of 4 of the following is required to diagnose BV
    • Clue cells
    • Whiff test positive
    • Grey-white homogenous discharge
    • pH > 5.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male with a history of epilepsy presents to the dentist with complaints of difficulty in eating and cleaning the teeth. On Examination, the findings were shown as seen in the diagram below. The patient reports that he has been taking an anti-epileptic drug for the past six months, and his symptoms began to appear gradually over the past few weeks. Which of the following anti-epileptic drugs is likely to produce these adverse effects?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Phenytoin

The patient's symptoms are consistent with gum hypertrophy caused by phenytoin. It can lead to dental problems such as difficulty in eating and cleaning the teeth.

Important drugs causing gum hypertrophy are:

  • Phenytoin
  • Cyclosporine
  • Calcium channel blockers

Carbamazepine is an anti-epileptic drug that can cause ataxia and dizziness, but it does not commonly cause gingival hyperplasia. Gabapentin and levetiracetam are other anti-epileptic drugs that do not typically cause nystagmus, ataxia, or gingival hyperplasia. Therefore, the correct answer is D) Phenytoin.

questions.text: A 28-year-old patient presents with the sadness of mood, frequent crying spells, insomnia, occasional suicidal thoughts, and lack of energy. The psychiatrist decides to start him on antidepressants, but the patient mentions that he is about to get married in one month and is concerned about the potential sexual side effects of the medication. Which of the following antidepressants should be prescribed to this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Mirtazapine

The patient's symptoms are suggestive of depression, and it is appropriate to initiate the antidepressant therapy. However, the patient's concern regarding potential sexual side effects should be taken into consideration when choosing the appropriate medication.

Mirtazapine is an atypical antidepressant that acts as a noradrenergic and specific serotonergic antidepressant (NaSSA). Mirtazapine has a lower incidence of sexual side effects compared to SSRIs and SNRIs, making it a suitable choice for this patient who is concerned about the potential impact on his sexual function. Apart from mirtazapine, bupropion is another antidepressant that has a very low incidence of sexual side effects.

Option A. Sertraline is a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI) that is commonly used to treat depression. However, SSRIs are known to cause sexual side effects such as decreased libido, delayed ejaculation, and poor erection in some patients.

Option B. Venlafaxine is a serotonin-norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor (SNRI) used to treat depression. While SNRIs are also effective in treating depression, they may cause similar sexual side effects as SSRIs due to their effect on serotonin.

Option D. Escitalopram is another SSRI used to treat depression. Like sertraline, it may cause sexual side effects due to its impact on serotonin.

questions.text: Which of the following is not seen in heart failure?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Pulmonary Oligemia

In heart failure, cardiomegaly is usually associated, and there is fluid accumulation in the lungs, which can cause interstitial edema. This can be seen on chest radiographs as Kerley B lines and interlobular septal thickening.

However, pulmonary oligemia, which is a decrease in lung vascular markings due to reduced blood flow to the lungs, is not seen in heart failure. It can be seen in conditions such as TOF, Ebstein anomaly and tricuspid atresia.

questions.solution:
Ans. A. 1-b, 2-c, 3-d, 4-a

Some other diseases & special scales seen in them:

questions.text:
Which of the following are branches of the anterior division of the internal iliac artery?

  1. Superior gluteal artery
  2. Inferior gluteal artery
  3. Superior vesical artery
  4. Middle rectal artery
  5. Inferior vesical artery
  6. Vaginal artery
questions.solution:
Ans. C. 2, 3, 4, 5, 6

The branches from the anterior division include 2, 3, 4, 5, 6.

The internal iliac artery is the major artery of the pelvis. At the superior border of the greater sciatic foramen in the pelvis, it divides into anterior and posterior trunks.

 

Branches of the anterior trunk of the internal iliac artery:

1. Obturator artery

2. Superior vesical artery

3. Inferior vesical artery

4. Inferior gluteal artery

5. Middle rectal artery

6. Vaginal artery (in females)

7. Uterine artery (in females)

8. Internal pudendal artery

Branches of the posterior trunk of the internal iliac artery:

• Iliolumbar artery

• Lateral sacral arteries

• Superior gluteal artery

questions.text: Which procedure is shown in the following picture?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Maxillary nerve block
The foramen rotundum is the point at which the maxillary nerve leaves the skull and splits into terminal branches. All branches (zygomatic branches, superior alveolar nerve, pterygopalatine and parasympathetic branches, palatine and pharyngeal branches, etc.) develop in the pterygopalatine fossa, with the exception of the middle meningeal nerve (the intracranial branch that innervates the dura mater). 

For major cancer surgery involving the maxilla, ethmoidal sinus, and pterigomaxillary or infratemporal fossa, this nerve block is primarily provided as an adjuvant to general anaesthesia. Bilateral maxillary nerve blocks help children's perioperative analgesia and encourage a quick return to feeding after congenital cleft palate repair. A maxillary nerve block may be beneficial for a variety of additional treatments, including the treatment of trigeminal neuralgias and the management of maxillary injuries (Lefort I).

The most reliable technique appears to be the suprazygomatic one (shown in the figure), which can be applied to both paediatric and adult patients. The patient is positioned supine with their head neutral. The angle created by the superior edge of the zygomatic arch below and the forward-facing posterior orbital rim is where the needle entrance point is located. The greater wing of the sphenoid is reached at a depth of about 10-15 mm by inserting a needle (22 to 25 gauge) perpendicular to the skin. To reach the pterygopalatine fossa, the needle is then moved 35–45 mm in a caudal and posterior manner. 0.1 mL kg-1 up to maximum of 5 mL of local anaesthetic solution is gently given after negative aspiration test for blood.

choices.text: Reports of Fingerprint Bureau

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT an exception to oral evidence in court?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Post-mortem reports

Oral evidence is more important than documentary evidence because it allows cross-examination.

Usually direct oral evidence by witness is preferred, however in certain exceptional conditions documentary evidence itself is accepted even without direct oral evidence. These exceptions are:

  1. Dying declaration: 
  2. Expert opinions expressed in a book:
  3. Deposition of a medical witness taken in a lower court:
  4. Evidence given by a witness in a previous judicial proceeding:
  5. Statements by persons who cannot be called as witnesses: e.g dead, untraceable etc..
  6. Report of certain government scientific experts:
    1. Chemical Examiner 
    2. Chief Controller of Explosives,
    3. Director of Fingerprint Bureau, 
    4. Director of a Central Forensic Science Laboratory
  7. Public records: e.g. birth and death certificates, certificates of marriage, etc.
  8. Hospital records: Routine entries such as date of admission, date of discharge etc..

A medical opinion is subjective and subject to interpretation and further cross questioning. Hence medical opinion in injury report, post-mortem report, report on sexual offences, Age report, Medicolegal certificates etc. are never admissible in court as document alone, they must be accompanied by the oral evidence of concerned Doctor.

questions.text: A victim of road traffic accident was brought into the casualty with shortness of breath and pain in the right upper part of his chest. Inspection revealed bruising over the right chest wall. On palpation, there was associated tenderness in the area and a chest X-ray showed the following picture. Which of these is the first step of definitive management in this case?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Opiate analgesia, oxygen, chest physiotherapy

This is a case of multiple rib fractures due to blunt trauma to chest. When two or more ribs (according to ATLS) are fractured in two or more places, it results in a flail chest. The blunt force typically also produces an underlying pulmonary contusion.

The chest wall shows paradoxical motion of the flail segment. On inspiration, the loose segment is displaced inwards while the rest of the chest wall moves out, and vice-versa. There occurs voluntary splinting of the chest wall due to the pain and this, along with underlying lung contusion can result in hypoxia.

 

Management:

Definitive treatment of flail chest and pulmonary contusion involves ensuring adequate oxygenation, providing analgesia to improve ventilation and chest physiotherapy.

Analgesia can be achieved with intravenous narcotics or topical intra-pleural anaesthetic administration through an already inserted chest tube.

Ventilation is reserved for patients developing respiratory failure despite adequate analgesia and oxygen.

Internal fixation of fractures done in select cases with prolonged mechanical ventilation or severe chest injury and pulmonary contusion.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man with a history of myocardial infarction and congestive heart failure is comfortable at rest. However, when walking to his car, he develops dyspnea, fatigue, and sometimes palpitations. He must rest for several minutes before these symptoms resolve. Which of the following is his New York Heart Association classification?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Class III

The New York Heart Association (NYHA) classification isa tool to define criteria that describe the functional ability and clinical manifestations of patients in heart failure. It is also used in patients with pulmonary hypertension. These criteria have been shown to have prognostic value with worsening survival as class increases.

They are also useful to clinicians when reading studies to understand the entry and exclusion criteria of large clinical trials. Class I is used for patients with no limiting symptoms,

class II is for patients with slight or mild limitation, class III implies no symptoms at rest but dyspnea or angina or palpitations with little exertion and patients are moderately limited, and class IV is severely limited so that even minimal activity causes symptoms.

Treatment guidelines also frequently base recommendation so on these clinical stages. This patient has symptoms with mild exertion but is comfortable at rest; therefore, he is NYHA class III.

questions.text: Maximum cell size in bacterial cell growth cycle is seen in which phase?
questions.solution: Ans. A. Lag phase

questions.text: A 32y woman is seeking a contraceptive method. The gynaecologist prescribes the below shown contraceptive. Which of the following describes best the mechanism of action of this contraceptive?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Endometrial atrophy

  • This is a MIRENA (LNG-IUS)
  • Mirena is a type of Levonorgestrel – Intrauterine System (LNG-IUS)
  • It contains levonorgestrel – 52 mg in total with a release rate of 20μg/ day
  • Effective life: 5 years
  • Uses: 
    • Contraception
    • Non contraceptive uses (Mnemonic: Mirena Safekeeps Endangered Animals)
      • Endometriosis
      • Symptomatic fibroid (not distorting the cavity)
      • Endometrial hyperplasia
      • Adenomyosis
  • There is no indication for use of LNG-IUS in an asymptomatic fibroid
  • Mechanism of Action:
    • Endometrial atrophy
    • Cervical mucus thickening
  • Contraindications to Mirena:
    • Unexplained uterine or vaginal bleeding
    • Post abortal sepsis
    • Puerperal sepsis
    • Endometrial cancer
    • Cervical cancer
    • Gestational trophoblastic neoplasia
    • Current Pelvic inflammatory disease
    • Genital Tuberculosis
    • Large fibroid distorting the uterine cavity
    • Mullerian anomalies distorting the uterine cavity

Ref: Page no 272, Shaw’s Textbook of Gynecology, 16th edition

questions.text: A 60-year-old female with a history of glaucoma presents to the ophthalmologist with complaints of blurred vision and eye irritation. The patient reports that she has been using an anti-glaucoma medication for the past six months, and her symptoms began to appear gradually over the past few weeks. Upon further evaluation, it is discovered that the patient has experienced darkening of the iris and eyelid skin as well as increased length, thickness, and pigmentation of the eyelashes. Which of the following anti-glaucoma drugs is likely to produce these adverse effects?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Latanoprost

  • The patient's symptoms are consistent with the known side effects of latanoprost, which is a prostaglandin analog used in the treatment of glaucoma.
  • Latanoprost can cause:
    • Pigmentation of Iris: It is also known as heterochromia iridis
    • Growth of Eyelashes: It is also called hypertrichosis
    • Macular Edema
    • Worsening of inflammation: So contraindicated in patients with uveitis.

choices.text: Type C fibres are small unmyelinated nerve fibres that conduct impulses at low velocities
Type A fibres are the typically large and medium-sized myelinated fibres of spinal nerves
Type B are further subdivided into α, β, and δ fibres
Subset of type A fibres has conduction velocity between 70-120 m/s

questions.text: Physiologists divided the nerve fibres into specific groups based on the myelination and thickness of nerve fibres. Select the incorrect characteristic of nerve fibres in different groups?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Type B fibres are further subdivided into α, β, and δ fibres

Subsets of type A fibres are α, β, γ, and δ fibres.

  • In the “general classification” of nerve fibres, the fibres are divided into types A and C; the type A fibres are further subdivided into α, β, γ, and δ fibres. Type A fibres are the typically large and medium-sized myelinated fibres of spinal nerves. Type C fibres are small unmyelinated nerve fibres that conduct impulses at low velocities. The C fibres constitute more than half of the sensory fibres in most peripheral nerves, as well as all the postganglionic autonomic fibres.
  • Option A. Type C fibres are small unmyelinated nerve fibres that conduct impulses at low velocities.
  • Option B. Type A fibres are the typically large and medium-sized myelinated fibres of spinal nerves.
  • Option D. Subsets of type A fibres have conduction velocities between 70-120 m/s.

questions.text: A study was done in 3 states to see the mean blood pressure in each community. Health workers were assigned and they visited each house in the three communities. Mean blood pressure in each community was found and compared. What type of study design is represented here?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Cross-sectional study

CROSS SECTIONAL STUDY:

  • Is based on the single examination of a cross-section of a population ‘at one point of time’, results of sample are then projected to whole population
    • Provides ‘Prevalence of the disease’ under study
    • More useful for chronic diseases
    • Tells about distribution of a disease in a population, ‘rather than its aetiology’
    • Gives ‘Snapshot of a population’
    • Cannot establish causality as ‘does not establish time sequence’
  • In the given question, A study was done in 3 states to see the mean blood pressure in each community where health workers visited each house in the three communities where mean blood pressure in each community was found and compared. So, here the study was carried out at a given time, neither prospectively nor retrospectively. Only prevalence of hypertension can be calculated, and aetiology cannot be found out.

 

Ref: Park 27/e p77

questions.text: A patient Vinod, who has taken the first COVID vaccine comes for the second dose. A nurse noticed that the shoulder was flabby, flat, and was asymmetrical. There was an associated loss of contour of the shoulder joint. Injury to which of the structures might have resulted and was avoidable?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Deltoid muscle

The given clinical case is suggestive of deltoid muscle palsy. in case of IM injection at shoulder region chances for axillary nerve injury. axillary nerve supplies deltoid & teres minor only .

Note:

Injury to the axillary nerve can lead to:

  • Weakness of abduction and lateral rotation of the arm
  • Retropulsion (extension of the shoulder with the arm abducted to 90 degrees) is impossible.
  • Atrophy of the Deltoid muscle leading to the loss of muscle contours of the shoulder
  • Loss of sensation in the Regimental badge area

Upper (superior) lateral cutaneous nerve of the arm (Option-C) that innervates the skin over the lower deltoid (regimental badge area). Thus, this is not the best of the given four options.

The images below show the Sargent /regimental badge sign and the various anatomical structures that can be appreciated in the transverse section of the shoulder joint respectively.

questions.text: A bodybuilder starts eating raw eggs for protein. He developed fatigue on moderate exercise. The doctor prescribes a vitamin. Which enzyme will be negatively affected in him?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Pyruvate Carboxylase

  • Raw eggs contain protein Avidin → tightly binds to Biotin (Vitamin B7) and is excreted along with biotin
  • Biotin is required for all carboxylases; all carboxylases requires ATP also.
  • So, enzyme affected is carboxylase which requires Biotin as coenzyme
  • Pyruvate Carboxylase is the first enzyme of gluconeogenesis,

Incorrect Answers:

Option D. Glycogen Phosphorylase

  • Rate limiting enzyme of Glycogenolysis
  • requires vitamin B6 pyridoxal phosphate
  • no relation with glycogen phosphorylase and egg avidin

Option A. Glucose 6 phosphatase

  • Common enzyme in gluconeogenesis and glycogenolysis.
  • Deficiency lead to hypoglycemia and that is called Von Gierke’s disease (Type 1 glycogen storage disease).
  • Von Gierke’s disease is the most common glycogen storage disease especially in children.

questions.text: 65-year-old man presents with progressive dyspnoea & pulmonary function testing was done. FEV1 is 2.5 L (78% predicted), FVC is 4.00 L (94% predicted), and the FEV1/FVC ratio is 62.5%. The flow-volume curve is shown. What is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Subglottic stenosis

A fixed central airflow obstruction results in flattening of the flow-volume loop in both inspiration and expiration, yielding the characteristic boxlike effect, as shown in this patient’s flow-volume loop. Examples of fixed airflow obstruction include tracheal stenosis and an obstructing central airway tumor.

questions.text: A patient was brought to the hospital with fever, headache and neck stiffness. CSF tap showed increased protein, mildly decreased glucose and lymphocytosis. The CSF tap image with its microscopic picture is given below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution: Ans. A. TB meningitis

choices.text: Remove the IUCD with a hook

questions.text: A 24y P2L2 who does not want more children presents to the OPD as she cannot feel the thread of the Multiload 375 that was inserted 3 years earlier. Her last menstrual period was 3 weeks earlier. On examination, the cervix appears normal, and the thread is not seen. A transvaginal scan shows the following image. What is the next best step?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Reassure her

  • A missing thread of an intra-uterine device could be because of
    • Thread fallen off
    • Thread coiled inside the cervix
    • IUCD expelled out
    • IUCD perforated the uterus and is in the abdomen/ pelvis
    • Pregnancy
  • The initial step in a missing thread is a TVS (ultrasound) to see if the IUCD is in the uterus
  • In this case, the image shows the IUCD in the uterus in a normal position
  • If the IUCD is in the uterus and the patient doesn’t want to conceive, nothing needs to be done. Once 5 years are completed (As she has a multiload 375), the IUCD should be replaced
  • If the patient wants it to be removed, then removal can be done using a
    • IUCD hook
    • Long artery forceps
    • Hysteroscopic removal
  • If the IUCD is not seen in utero, then next step is: X-Ray Abdomen and Pelvis (with a uterine sound) to see where the IUCD is in relation to the sound. If it is the abdomen/ pelvis, laparoscopy or laparotomy is done to remove it.

questions.text: A 33-year-old woman presents with a 3-day history of seeing "spots" floating around in her right eye. Today, she notes streaks of light in the same eye accompanied by a "shadow" in her peripheral vision that moves when looking up and down. Her medical history is significant for migraine headaches; however, she has never had such visual symptoms with her headaches. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Retinal detachment

The history suggests retinal detachment. As people age, the vitreous begins to detach from the retina and can cause the perception of "floaters," which represent vitreous condensation. In certain eyes, the normal process of the vitreous detaching from the retina may cause a peripheral "horseshoe" tear in susceptible areas of the retina. The tear allows fluid within the vitreous to accumulate under the retina and cause a detachment. When the retina is partially detached and the eye moves, the patient may notice a "shadow" that corresponds to the torn retina. A retinal detachment is considered an ophthalmic emergency because the detachment can progress to the fovea and threaten central vision. When any patient complains of the new appearance of flashes of light or floaters, a dilated retinal examination should be performed by an ophthalmologist to rule out retinal tear or detachment.1

Ref: Am J Ophthalmol; Hikichi T, Trempe CL. Relationship between floaters, light flashes, or both, and complications of posterior vitreous detachment. 1994; 117:593-598.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents with fatigue, night sweats, and weight loss. A complete blood count (CBC) is performed, and the peripheral blood smear shows the presence of cells with increased basophilic cytoplasm, granulocytic precursors, and a high percentage of blasts. A bone marrow biopsy is performed. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis for this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Chronic myeloid leukaemia (CML)

The bone marrow aspirate image shows hypercellularity, increased basophilic cytoplasm, and increased blasts, which are characteristic findings in chronic myeloid leukaemia (CML). CML is a myeloproliferative neoplasm characterized Philadelphia chromosome [t (9;22)].

Option A. Acute myeloid leukaemia (AML), typically presents with a higher percentage of blasts in the bone marrow aspirate, often >20%, and may show Auer rods, which are not seen in the provided image.

Option B. Chronic lymphocytic leukaemia (CLL), is a lymphoproliferative disorder that typically presents with a high percentage of small lymphocytes in the peripheral blood and bone marrow, and does not show the basophilic cytoplasm and blasts seen in the provided image.

Option D. Multiple myeloma, is a plasma cell neoplasm characterized by the presence of monoclonal plasma cells in the bone marrow, and does not show the findings of increased basophilic cytoplasm and blasts seen in the provided image.

questions.text: A 36-year-old patient who has been smoking for the past 16 years expresses a desire to quit smoking. Which medication is most effective for this patient in smoking cessation?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Varenicline

Varenicline is a partial agonist of the α4β2 nicotinic acetylcholine receptor and helps reduce nicotine cravings and withdrawal symptoms while also blocking the rewarding effects of nicotine. Varenicline has been shown to be more effective than other medications for smoking cessation in various clinical trials and is considered the first-line pharmacological treatment.

Option B. Naltrexone is an opioid antagonist primarily used for treating alcohol and opioid use disorders.

Option C. Bupropion is an atypical antidepressant and a norepinephrine-dopamine reuptake inhibitor. It is also used for smoking cessation, as it can help reduce cravings and withdrawal symptoms. Although it is an effective option, varenicline has been shown to be more effective in promoting smoking cessation.

Option D. Nicotine patches are a form of nicotine replacement therapy (NRT), which provides nicotine in a controlled manner to help reduce withdrawal symptoms and cravings. While NRT can be effective, varenicline has been found to be more effective in smoking cessation.

questions.text: A 30-year-old female came to the OPD with complaints of backache. On examination, her eyes and pinna revealed blackish discoloration. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Alkaptonuria  

Intervertebral disc calcification is seen in the image suggestive of alkaptonuria.

Deficiency: Homogentisic oxidase 

Hyperpigmentation of ears and eyes suggestive of ochronosis is a clue. It is seen due to excessive build-up of homogentisic acid. 

Other options:

Fluorosis – Increased bone density with interosseous ligament ossification  

DISH    VS Ankylosing spondylitis

questions.text: A child presents to you with itchy lesions on the scalp with hair loss as shown in the image below. What would be the next best step?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. KOH mount

The above image shows tinea capitis, which presents with a well-demarcated scaly patch in which hair shafts are broken off just above the skin resulting in scarring or non-scarring alopecia. KOH mount is useful for the depicted condition.

Tinea capitis variants:

 

Ectothrix (Spores & fungus present outside the hair shaft)

Endothrix (Spores & fungi present inside the hair shaft)

Kerion presents in Children with boggy swelling, easily pluckable hair, with regional lymphadenopathy. It is a severe inflammatory type of tinea capitis. The most common causative organisms of kerion are Zoophilic dermatophytes, T. verrucosum and T. mentagrophytes. In severe cases, there may be pus along with sinus formation.

Kerion:

  • Lesion: boggy indurated scalp swelling
  • Easily pluckable hair associated with regional lymohadenopathy
  • Investigation: 10% KOH mount

Treatment: DOC overall and for Microsporum à Griseofulvin

DOC for Trichophyton à Terbinafine.

 

Ref: Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, Volume II, 9th Edition, Chapter 32, Page no. 32.3

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presents to the clinic with complaints of chronic lower back pain and stiffness that has been progressively worsening over the past few months. He also reports a family history of similar symptoms. After conducting a physical examination, the physician suspects that the patient may be suffering from ankylosing spondylitis. Which of these is most specific for ankylosing spondylitis:
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Bilateral Sacroiliitis

Sacroiliitis is most specific for diagnosis of Ankylosing Spondylitis.

Modified New York Criterion for Ankylosing Spondylitis:

Essential Criterion:

  • Radiographic Sacroiliitis

Supporting Criterion:

  • Inflammatory Back Pain
  • Reduced Chest Expansion
  • Reduced Lumbar Movement

Ankylosing spondylitis is diagnosed with presence of essential criterion with one of the supporting criterion being positive.

questions.text: A woman presents with a breast tumour of size 6 x 3cm, with adherence to the pectoralis major muscle. Only the dermis of the overlying skin is found to be involved. As her surgeon, what will you designate her T (tumour) staging as?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. T3

The tumour is of size 6cm. Hence, it is stage T3 (>5cm).

Irrelevant to the size of the tumour, if the tumour shows extension to the chest wall or skin, it is classified as T4. However, there two exceptions:

  • Invasion or adherence to Pectoralis muscle in the absence of chest wall involvement does not qualify as T4.
  • Similarly, involvement of the dermis alone does not qualify as T4.
    • T4a: chest wall involvement (except pectoralis major)
    • T4b: skin involvement in the form of ulceration, peaud’orange, satellite nodules
    • T4c: T4a + T4b
    • T4d: inflammatory breast carcinoma (typical skin change involving >1/3rd of breast)

questions.text: A 78-year-old woman is admitted to the ICU with pneumonia. Since she was in marked respiratory distress, she was intubated in the emergency. The ventilator is set in the assist control mode with a RR of 24 breaths/min, tidal volume of 6 mL/kg, FiO2 of 1.0 and PEEP of 12 cmH2O. An ABG is performed – the results are pH of 7.20, PaCO2 of 32 mmHg, and PaO2 of 54 mmHg. What is the cause of the hypoxemia?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Shunt

In this patient presenting with multilobar pneumonia, hypoxemia is present that does not correct with 100% O2. The inability to overcome hypoxemia or the lack of a notable increase in PaO2 or SaO2 with increasing fraction of inspired oxygen physiologically defines a shunt. A shunt occurs when deoxygenated blood is transported to the left heart and systemic circulation without having the capability of becoming oxygenated (right-to-left shunt).

questions.text: What is the mechanism of action of the toxin produced by the bacterium shown in the figure below?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. ADP-ribosylation of EF2

Given picture shows:

  • Club-shaped gram-positive bacilli
  • Arranged in cuneiform or Chinese letter pattern
  • Suggestive of Corynebacterium diphtheriae
  • The mechanism of action of diphtheria toxin is ADP ribosylation of elongation factor-2, leading to inhibition of protein synthesis.

Toxins that act by inhibiting protein synthesis:

DPSS

  • Diphtheria toxin
  • Pseudomonas toxin
  • Shiga toxin
  • Shiga like toxin or verotoxin of EHEC

Toxins that act by increasing cAMP:

BVEB

  • Bacillus anthrax
  • Vibrio cholarae
  • ETEC
  • Bordetella pertusis

questions.text:
Which characteristics are risk factors for malignant transformation of the structural lesion shown in the hysteroscopic image?

 

  1. Tamoxifen use
  2. Postmenopausal state
  3. Size > 1.5 cm
  4. Use of OCPs
  5. Early menopause
questions.solution:
Ans. A. 1, 2, 3

  • This is an endometrial polyp
  • Most polyps are benign
  • Premalignant or malignant transformation develops in only approximately 5 percent
  • Risk factors for malignant transformation are:
    • Postmenopausal status
    • Larger polyp size (> 1.5 cm)
    • Tamoxifen use
    • Associated endometrial hyperplasia
    • Early menarche and late menopause (more estrogenic exposure)
  • OCPs are protective
  • Treatment of endometrial polyp: Hysteroscopic resection

choices.text: Oedema, erythema and tenderness of the eyelids

questions.text: A 22-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department because of a 1-day history of double vision and rapidly worsening pain and swelling of her right eye. She had an upper respiratory infection a week ago after which she has had nasal congestion, recurrent headaches and a purulent nasal discharge. She took antibiotics for her respiratory tract infection but did not complete the course. She has asthma treated with Theophylline and inhaled beta-adrenergic agonist and corticosteroids. She appears to be in severe distress. Her temperature is 38.5°C pulse is 100/min and BP is 130/80 mmHg. Ophthalmic examination of the right eye, shows proptosis and diffuse oedema, erythema and tenderness of the eyelids. Right eye movements are restricted and painful in all directions. The pupils are equal and reactive to light. There is tenderness to palpation over the right cheek and purulent nasal discharge in the right nasal cavity. The left eye shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show a leukocyte count of 12,000 per millimetre cube. Which of the following provides the strongest indication for administering intravenous antibiotics to this patient?
questions.solution: Ans. D. Pain with Eye Movements

choices.text: Aducanumab is an anticoagulant drug used to prevent blood clots
Aducanumab is a monoclonal antibody used in the treatment of Alzheimer's disease
Aducanumab is a chemotherapy drug used in the treatment of cancer
Aducanumab is a vaccine used to prevent HIV infection

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding Aducanumab?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Aducanumab is a monoclonal antibody used in the treatment of Alzheimer's disease.

  • Aducanumab is a monoclonal antibody that targets amyloid A beta, a protein that forms plaques in the brains of people with Alzheimer's disease.
  • It is the drug that targets the underlying cause of Alzheimer’s disease.
  • Another drug used for same purpose and acting by same mechanism is lecanemab.

choices.text: Facilitated Diffusion – Ca2+ into Sarcoplasmic Reticulum

questions.text: Identify the correctly matched pair amongst the following?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Simple Diffusion – O2

  • Oxygen diffuses from alveoli into the pulmonary blood by simple diffusion.
  • Oxygen is lipid soluble, and it can pass through lipid bilayer, it does not need ion channel, hence option D can be ruled out.
  • Option B. This is not by facilitated diffusion – it is a primary active transport. Ca2+ into sarcoplasmic reticulum requires SERCA (Sarco Endoplasmic Reticulum Calcium Transport ATPase). The pump is found in the membrane of the sarcoplasmic reticulum. In some cases, it is so plentiful that it may make up 90% of the protein there. Powered by ATP, it pumps calcium ions back into the sarcoplasmic reticulum, reducing the calcium level around the actin and myosin filaments and allowing the muscle to relax.
  • Nervous stimulation leads to depolarization of the sarcolemma (muscle membrane) that triggers calcium ions’ release from the sarcoplasmic reticulum.
  • Option C. Glucose – secondary active transport facilitated by Sodium-Glucose transporter. So, this can be ruled out.
  • Option D. Ion channel transport – There are ion channels specific for K+, Na+, Ca2+, and Cl–, as well as channels that are nonselective for cations or anions.
  • Each type of channel exists in multiple forms with diverse properties. Most are made up of identical or very similar sub units.

choices.text: Bypassing carbamoyl phosphate synthetase II (CPS-II)

questions.text: A neonate is lethargic, drowsy, and irritable with blood analysis showing hyperammonemia and orotic aciduria. Considering this patient, orotic acid levels are high due to which of the following?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Bypassing carbamoyl phosphate synthetase II (CPS-II)

  • The rate limiting step for de novo pyrimidine synthesis is carbamoyl phosphate synthetase II (CPS-II), which produces carbamoyl phosphate in the cytoplasm.
  • In an OTC deficiency, the carbamoyl phosphate produced in the mitochondria leaks into the cytoplasm leading to orotic acid synthesis as the regulated step of the pathway is being bypassed.

Incorrect answers:

Options A & B. The elevated ammonia is not a substrate of CPS-II and which glutamine is also elevated and is a substrate of CPS-II, higher glutamine concentrations will not overcome enzyme inhibition by its allosteric inhibitor, Uridine triphosphate (UTP).

Option D. Aspartate transcarbamoylase is the regulated step of pyrimidine biosynthesis in many prokaryotic cells, but not in humans. This step is necessary for pyrimidines to be synthesized starting with carbamoyl phosphate.

 

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e, p. 205

questions.text: A 63-year-old man with COPD presents to you with dyspnea. Which of the following therapies is most likely to prolong his survival?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Oxygen

The only therapies that have been proven to improve survival in patients with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) are smoking cessation, oxygen in patients with resting hypoxemia, and lung volume reduction surgery in a very small subset of highly selected patients. This patient probably has resting hypoxemia resulting from the presence of an elevated jugular venous pulse, pedal edema, and elevated hematocrit. Theophylline has been shown to increase exercise tolerance in patients with COPD through a mechanism other than bronchodilation. Oral glucocorticoids are not indicated in the absence of an acute exacerbation and may lead to complications if they are used indiscriminately. Atenolol and enalapril have no specific role in therapy for COPD but are often used when there is concomitant hypertension or cardiovascular disease.

questions.text: A child presents with sepsis. The bacteria isolated from blood showed beta hemolysis on blood agar, resistance to bacitracin, and a positive cAMP test. The most probable organism causing infection is:
questions.solution: Ans. B. Streptococcus agalactiae

questions.text: Sophie is a 2-year-old girl who has been experiencing episodes of fainting and stiffness. These episodes are typically triggered by pain, such as when she falls or bumps into something. During the episodes, Sophie becomes stiff and unresponsive for a few seconds before losing consciousness and falling to the ground. Her parents take her to a paediatrician, who refers her to a neurologist for further evaluation. Identify the condition:
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Reflex anoxic seizures

Reflex anoxic seizures will happen when you hurt yourself, as it increases sensitivity to vagus nerve.

Patient will present as severe bradycardia, becomes pale with LOC & seizures.

choices.text: a wave of JVP, first heart sound, c wave of JVP, second heart sound
c wave of JVP, first heart sound, a wave of JVP, second heart sound
First heart sound, c wave of JVP, a wave of JVP, second heart sound
First heart sound, a wave of JVP, c wave of JVP, second heart sound

questions.text: Arrange the following in the correct sequence of events in the cardiac cycle?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. a wave of JVP, first heart sound, c wave of JVP, second heart sound

  • The upward deflections are the "a" (atrial contraction), "c" (ventricular contraction and resulting bulging of tricuspid into the right atrium during isovolumetric systole) and "v" = venous filling
  • The downward deflections of the wave are the "x" descent (the atrium relaxes and the tricuspid valve moves downward) and the "y" descent (filling of ventricle after tricuspid opening.

 

a wave – right atrial contracts; some blood is pushed back up into the internal jugular vein

x descent – relaxation of right atrium causing drop in pressure

c wave – tricuspid valve closes and right ventricle contracts

x’ descent – end of right ventricular contraction creates extra space within pericardium, allowing right atrium to begin filling with blood

v wave – filling of right atrium against a closed tricuspid valve

y descent – tricuspid valve opens and blood from right atrium begins to fill the ventricles

choices.text: Anion gap metabolic acidosis plus metabolic alkalosis
Anion gap metabolic acidosis plus normal anion gap metabolic acidosis

questions.text:
A patient has the following laboratory findings:

 

Sodium – 138 mEq/L

Potassium – 4.4 mEq/L

Chloride – 112 mEq/L

Bicarbonate – 8.0 mEq/L

Arterial pH – 7.21

Which of the following is the most likely acid-base status?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Anion gap metabolic acidosis plus normal anion gap metabolic acidosis

The most likely acid-base status is anion gap metabolic acidosis plus normal anion gap metabolic acidosis. The patient has metabolic acidosis, as shown by the low pH and decreased serum bicarbonate values. The anion gap, which is normally 8 to 10 mEq/L ± 2 mEq/L (8 to 10 mmol/L ± 2.0 mmol/L), is calculated by the following formula: sodium − (chloride + bicarbonate). In this patient, the anion gap is 18 mEq/L (18 mmol/L), which is elevated. One can then determine what the serum bicarbonate level would have been if the patient did not have anion gap metabolic acidosis by adding back the increase (from normal) in anion gap (in this instance, 8 mEq/L [8.0 mmol/L] [that is, 18 – 10]) to the patient's current serum bicarbonate level. Adding 8 mEq/L (8 mmol/L) to 8 mEq/L (8 mmol/L) equals 16 mEq/L (16 mmol/L), which means that the bicarbonate level still would have been low at 16 mEq/L (16 mmol/L) if the patient did not have anion gap metabolic acidosis. This result suggests the presence of superimposed normal anion gap metabolic acidosis.

questions.text: A person presents with pneumonia. His sputum was sent for culture. The bacterium obtained showed gram positive cocci in chains on microscopy and alpha haemolytic colonies on sheep agar. Which of the following will help in confirming the diagnosis?
questions.solution: Ans. B. Optochin

choices.text: Ruptured corpus luteum cyst

questions.text: A 30y P1 with a last menstrual period 10 days ago presents to the emergency with complaints of worsening right pelvic pain. She says that she had sudden onset of sharp pain after bending over to pick up her child. The pain did not respond to acetaminophen and has intermittently worsened during the past several hours. She also had 2 episodes of vomiting.  On examination, there is abdominal guarding. Transvaginal sonography demonstrates an 8-cm enlarged right ovary. There is high impedance arterial flow of the ovary on colour Doppler. These findings are most consistent with which of the following clinical diagnoses?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Ovarian torsion

  • Findings in this case are consistent with a right ovarian torsion
  • The Doppler findings are suggestive of reduced flow which will not be seen in a haemorrhagic cyst or a ruptured corpus luteum

questions.text: Which of the following pituitary adenomas is likely to be hormonally ‘silent’?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Gonadotroph adenoma

Out of the given options, gondotroph adenoma can be associated with mass effects but are hormonally silent.

questions.text: Sarah is a 14-year-old girl who has been experiencing episodes of jerky movements and loss of consciousness. These episodes usually occur in the morning or after sleep deprivation, and they last only a few seconds. She has a habit of dropping objects like spoon and pencil from her hands and she notices repetitive muscle jerking while brushing her teeth. Sarah's parents take her to a neurologist for further evaluation. What is she diagnosed to be suffering from?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Juvenile myoclonic epilepsy

Juvenile myoclonic epilepsy – important points:

  • Patient will present with twitching of fingers and dropping of objects with isolated jerks
  • Gabra 1 gene mutation
  • Good prognosis
  • Sodium valproate (doc)

Extra point: abcc2: dubin johnson syndrome

questions.text: Name the method of losing heat as shown in the image below:
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Evaporation

The method of heat loss which has to happen is evaporation.

Method of heat loss from a cold surface is known as conduction.

Method of heat loss from an open window/fan is convection.

Method of heat loss when a baby is kept near a cold wall of nursery is radiation.

questions.text: The point X shown in the following enzyme kinetic plot represents which of the following value?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. -1/Km

  • In enzyme kinetics study, it is difficult to achieve high substrate concentrations to reach the maximal velocity conditions. So, ½ Vmax or Km is difficult to determine.
  • Thus, experimental data at lower concentrations is plotted as reciprocals à a straight line is obtained which when extrapolated gives the reciprocal of Km. This is called Lineweaver Burk Plot or Double Reciprocal Plot which can be derived from the Michaelis-Menten equation.
  • If we plot 1/v against 1/[S], it will give a straight line graph. X intercept is (-1/Km), from which the Km can be calculated.

 

Incorrect answers:

Option A. Km: From the graph, X intercept is (-1/Km), from which the Km can be calculated.

Option C. Km/Vmax: Slope is Km/Vmax.

Option D. 1/Vmax: Y intercept is 1/Vmax.

 

 

Ref: Harper 30/e, p. 80; Vasudevan 9/ed., p. 57

questions.text: Which of these is a true statement about use of compression stockings in varicose veins?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. No benefit in prevention or progression of disease

  • Compression hosiery relies on graduated external pressure to improve deep venous return and reduce venous pressures. It may be knee length or thigh length; there is no evidence which length of stocking is more effective and hence below-knee stockings are usually prescribed as they are easier to don and have much better patient acceptance.
  • Compression hosiery is classified according to the pressure it exerts: the British classification class 1 stockings exert pressure of 14–17 mmHg, class 2 exert 18–24 mmHg and class 3 exert 25–35 mmHg.
  • Compression hosiery significantly improves varicose vein symptoms but is not popular with patients, with compliance rates and long-term tolerance being universally poor.
  • There is no evidence to suggest that compression hosiery prevents the occurrence or progression of varicose veins.

questions.text: A 16y girl is brought to the OPD as she has not started her period. The patient’s 14y sister underwent menarche 2 years earlier and her mother began menstruating at age 13. She has no weight gain, headaches, nipple discharge or abdominal pain. She is not sexually active and is not using any method of contraception. She is physically active and is on her school’s basketball team. Her breast examination and pubic hair are Tanner stage IV. The abdomen is soft. The external genitalia appear normal. questions.text: In glycogen metabolism, a metabolically active important enzyme found in liver is converted from its inactive dephosphorylated state to its active phosphorylated state. Which of the following is true about this enzyme?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. More commonly seen in fasting state than in fed state

  • The enzyme in concern in this question is Glycogen Phosphorylase.
  • Glycogen Phosphorylase
    • It is rate limiting enzyme of glycogenolysis and active in phosphorylated state i.e. phosphorylation always activates this enzyme. (Option A is false)
    • Catecholamines stimulate this enzyme through cAMP, not directly. cAMP cause phosphorylation of protein kinases which in turn activate this enzyme by phosphorylation. (Option B is false)
    • Glycogenolysis is activated in fasting state, not in fed state. It helps to maintain blood glucose and can provide glucose up to 12-18 hours of fasting (Option C is true).
    • cAMP activates this enzyme, but calcium & calmodulin can also directly activate this enzyme without phosphorylation and without cAMP. (Option D is false as this enzyme is not always activated by cAMP).

questions.text: A young man presents with features of recurrent brief depressive disorder, each lasting for about 3 to 7 days, for over a year. He had history of occasional headache and episodes of swooning attack in between, usually precipitated by emotional events. His neuroimaging revealed agenesis of corpus callosum. He was experiencing swooning attacks as he became aware that some ‘unusual’ findings were present in his reports. Recurrent brief depression can be a manifestation of this congenital anomaly, and conversion disorder can be present as comorbid diagnosis perhaps due to ignorance and fear of this apparently innocuous congenital malformation. What is blood supply of corpus callosum?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Anterior cerebral artery and anterior communicating artery

Corpus callosum is connecting band of white matter in between 2 cerebral hemispheres.

It is mainly presenting on medial surface of brain. Main artery of medial surface is anterior cerebral artery.

Blood is supplied by the anterior cerebral artery and anterior communicating artery Corpus callosum is the largest fibre pathway of the brain. The parts of the corpus callosum are the rostrum, genu, trunk or body, and splenium.

The image below shows the parts of the corpus callosum:

Anterior cerebral artery is a branch of the internal carotid artery. The frontal branch of the anterior cerebral artery supplies the corpus callosum and the central branch which supplies the rostrum.

Central or perforating arteries arises from the Circle of Willis. They are again divided into the anteromedial, anterolateral, posteromedial and posterolateral groups. The anterior cerebral and anterior communicating artery give rise to anteromedial group which supplies the rostrum of the corpus callosum.

questions.text: The tensile strength of collagen fibres is provided by its triple helical structure, which can be most accurately described as which of the following level of protein structure?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Quaternary

  • The triple helical structure of collagen fibres that provides their tensile strength is most accurately described as a quaternary structure of proteins.
  • The quaternary structure refers to the arrangement of multiple polypeptide chains that form a protein complex. In the case of collagen fibers, the triple helix is a repeating structure formed by three polypeptide chains twisted together in a helical conformation.

Other Options:

The primary structure of a protein refers to its linear sequence of amino acids (Option A). The tertiary structure (Option C) refers to the 3D arrangement of the protein's secondary structures (Option B) and any additional folding or coiling. All of these structures are features of a single polypeptide chain. Although these structures are all part of triple helical collagen but the most accurate description of triple helix is it being the quaternary structure.

 

 

Ref: Harper’s Illustrated Biochemistry, 30th edition, page no. 37-42

questions.text: Shown below is a popular sign that occurs in acute appendicitis. What is the name of this sign?

questions.text: Which of the following assisted reproductive technologies (ART) techniques is shown in the image below?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Intracytoplasmic sperm injection (ICSI)

  • It is most applicable to male factor infertility.
  • During the micromanipulation technique of ICSI, cumulus cells surrounding an ovum are enzymatically digested, and a single sperm is directly injected through the zona pellucida and oocyte cell membrane.
  •  Pregnancy rates with ICSI are comparable with those achieved with IVF or other causes of infertility.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a treatment option for fistula in ano?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Internal sphincterotomy

It is used for anal fissures.

Surgery for fistula in ano:

  1. Fistulotomy involves division of all structures lying between the external and internal openings. It is therefore applied mainly to intersphincteric fistulae and trans-sphincteric fistulae involving less than 30% of the external sphincter (but not anterior fistulae in women)
  2. Fistulectomy involves coring out of the fistula, usually by diathermy cautery; it allows better definition of fistula anatomy than fistulotomy, especially the level at which the track crosses the sphincters and the presence of secondary extensions.

Setons: Loose setons are tied such that there is no tension upon the encircled tissue; there is no intent to cut the tissue. A variety of materials have been used but the seton should be non-absorbable, non-degenerative and comfortable. Tight or cutting setons are placed with the intention of cutting through the enclosed muscle. Loose setons are also used for long-term palliation to avoid septic and painful exacerbations by establishing effective drainage

Cutting setons aim to achieve the high fistula eradication rates associated with fistulotomy but without the degree of functional impairment endowed by division of the sphincters at a single stage.

LIFT: ligation on inter sphincteric fistula tract

LIFT involves disconnection of the internal opening from the fistula tract at the level of the intersphincteric plane and removal of the residual infected glands without dividing any part of the sphincter complex. The tract is then ligated and divided, the internal part is removed and the external part of the track is curetted and drained 

VAAFT: video assisted anal fistula tract excision

questions.text: A 1-day old baby is evaluated in the emergency department due to poor feeding, repeated bilious vomiting and not passing meconium since birth. Abdominal examination reveals a distended abdomen. Imaging shows the following picture. Identify the condition in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Meconium ileus

Image shows atretic colon (micro-colon) with small bowel obstruction on barium enema- suggestive of meconium ileus

  • Inspissated meconium (usually due to pancreatic insufficiency in a cystic fibrosis child) may cause a distal ileal obstruction.
  • An abdominal radiograph shows small bowel obstruction with a ground-glass appearance.
  • Simple cases are managed with a water-soluble hyperosmolar contrast enema (diatrizoate) using fluoroscopy in a well-hydrated neonate.
  • Complicated cases require a laparotomy and enterotomy for a luminal washout; a temporary stoma may be required. Postoperatively, N-acetylcysteine can be given by nasogastric tube and as enemas to loosen residual meconium.
  • Genetic investigations look for defects in the cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR) protein.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male patient who is a known alcoholic presented with complaints of chronic pain in the epigastric region with occasional flare-ups of the pain over a background discomfort. He also complains of greasy stools that stick to the pan. Which substance in stools can be measured to test for pancreatic function in this case?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Elastase

Measurement of the enzyme elastase in stools is a simple, specific and widely used pancreatic function test.

Pancreatic function tests:

Pancreatic exocrine function can be assessed by directly measuring pancreatic secretion in response to a standardised stimulus. The stimulus to secretion can be physiological, e.g. ingestion of a test meal, as in the Lundh test, or pharmacological, e.g. intravenous injection of a hormone such as secretin or CCK.

Duodenal intubation has to be performed with a triple-lumen tube so that the gastric and duodenal juices can be aspirated, and a non-absorbable marker such as polyethylene glycol is used to assess the completeness of the aspiration.

The nitroblue tetrazolium–para-aminobenzoic acid (NBT–PABA) test provides an indirect measure of pancreatic function. The substance is administered orally and degraded in the gut by a pancreatic enzyme, and the breakdown product (PABA) is absorbed by the intestine and excreted in the urine; its urinary level is measured.

Measurement of the enzyme elastase in stool is simple, specific and now used widely. A low level of faecal elastase indicates exocrine insufficiency.

questions.text: 27-year-old woman is admitted to the ICU after recent delivery of a full-term infant 3 days prior. The patient was found to have right hemiparesis and livedo reticularis. Lab reports – WBC 10200/μL, Hematocrit 35%, and platelet count of 13,000/μL. Peripheral smear reveals no schistocytes. Her Urea is 72 mg/dL, and her creatinine is 2.3 mg/dL. She has history of three prior pregnancy losses. Which of the following laboratory studies will best confirm the underlying etiology of her presentation?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Anticardiolipin antibody panel

The patient has thrombosis in vasculature of brain and likely had placental insufficiency in the three prior pregnancies, which makes the diagnosis of antiphospholipid antibody syndrome likely.

In addition, she has evidence of acute kidney injury, suggesting multisystem disease.

Thrombocytopenia may be due to hemolytic anemia, but the absence of schistocytes makes it less likely that she has thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura. Antinuclear antibody test is likely to be positive given the common overlap with SLE, but it is nonspecific.

questions.text: A 25-year-old patient with no significant medical history presents to the emergency department with a fever of 102°F and altered sensorium. Upon examination, you notice a petechial rash on the patient's arms and legs. You suspect meningococcal septicaemia. Which of the following antibiotics is recommended as the first-line empiric therapy?
