Ans. A. Ceftriaxone

  • Meningococcal septicaemia is a medical emergency that requires prompt antibiotic therapy.
  • Empiric therapy with intravenous ceftriaxone is recommended as the first-line treatment for suspected meningococcal septicaemia.
  • Penicillin G is an alternative option but is less commonly used due to increasing resistance.
  • Piperacillin-tazobactam and cotrimoxazole are not recommended as first-line treatments for meningococcal septicaemia.
  • Definitive therapy should be based on culture and susceptibility results.

DOC for empirical therapy of meningitis

Note:

  • Vancomycin is given to cover gram positive bacteria like Streptococcus pneumoniae and Staphylococcus (including MRSA)
  • Ampicillin is given to cover Listeria
  • Meropenem is given to cover gram negative bacteria
  • Cefotaxime can be used in place of ceftriaxone
  • Cefepime can be used in place of meropenem

questions.text: A 65-year-old male presents with symptoms of urinary urgency, frequency, and nocturia. He has been diagnosed with overactive bladder and his previous medication (oxybutynin) was not effective in managing his symptoms. questions.solution:
Ans. C. Mirabegron

  • Mirabegron is a beta-3 adrenergic receptor agonist that is used to treat symptoms of overactive bladder, including urinary urgency, frequency, and urge incontinence. It works by relaxing the detrusor muscle in the bladder, increasing its capacity and reducing the urge to urinate. In patients who have not responded to or have experienced side effects from antimuscarinic drugs like oxybutynin, mirabegron can be an effective alternative.
  • Option A (tolterodine) and option B (solifenacin) and option D (fesoterodine) are antimuscarinic drugs that are also used to treat overactive bladder.

questions.text: A 24y primigravida presents at 37 weeks gestation with headache, a BP of 170/102 mmHg and severe upper quadrant right abdominal pain. The incidence of SLH rupture in pregnancy is in less than 2% of pregnancies complicated by HELLP syndrome.

questions.text: A 70-year-old patient presented with decreased hearing in both ears, progressively increasing since 5 years. On otoscopy, tympanic membrane looked normal. Rinne’s test was positive on both sides and Weber’s test showed no response (no sounds were heard in any ear when tuning fork was kept on the forehead). Impedance showed type A curve with intact stapedial reflex. In pure tone audiometry among the following audiograms, what could be the correct one in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. 
The diagnosis in this patient is presbycusis (age-related sensorineural hearing loss). 
In Presbycusis, patients have sensorineural hearing loss. 
Picture A shows normal audiogram. 
Picture B shows conductive hearing loss. 
Picture C shows sensorineural hearing loss. 
Picture D shows mixed hearing loss. 

Pure Tone Audiometry –

Here, the amount of hearing loss can also be known along with the type of hearing loss. It is a subjective test.

2 curves will be there, dotted line represents bone conduction (BC) & continuous line represents air conduction (AC)

Left ear audiogram is plotted with blue ink and right ear audiogram is plotted with red ink. (RR – Right Red).

Whenever a pure tone audiometry is given, first see whether there is air-bone gap (Air conduction & Bone conduction curves are separated by a long gap?)

If there is no air-bone gap or very less gap, then it could be sensorineural hearing loss. Then search in the options for the conditions that cause sensorineural hearing loss (Meniere’s – B/L, acoustic neuroma – U/L, Noise induced hearing loss – B/L, presbycusis – B/L).

If there is a long separation in between the AC & BC curves, then it could be either conductive or mixed. First see the distantly separated curves are in the upper part of the graph or lower part. If occupying upper part, then it is conductive hearing loss and if occupying lower part, then it could be mixed. Accordingly search for the conditions that cause such type of hearing loss in the given options.

Dip at 2000Hz on BC curve – Otosclerosis

Dip at 4000Hz – Noise induced hearing loss

Cookie bite audiogram – congenital hearing loss mostly

Trough shaped audiogram – acoustic neuroma

Up-sloping curve with SNHL – Meniere’s disease (low frequencies involved)

Down-sloping curve with SNHL – presbycusis (high frequency loss) {Presbycusis – age-induced hearing loss. Rx – hearing aid}.

High frequency audiometry is used for detecting ototoxicity.

choices.text: Recent anal sex with child

questions.text: A police officer brings a 15-year-old male child to the doctor for medical examination. The mother of the child gives history of sexual assault of the child by his uncle since 2 years. A thorough examination is performed on the child. Anal examination shows features suggestive of:
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Repeated anal sex with child

Features of habitual passive agent in sodomy:

  • Loss of normal folds around anus
  • Skin around anus thickened & smooth
  • Lateral traction test positive

The normal looks like as below:

questions.text: A 26y woman who is currently living with her partner visits for cervical cancer screening. She has been in 3 earlier relationships. What is the screening method recommended?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. HPV

  • HPV is now the primary screening method for cervical cancer
  • WHO guidelines say
    • For general population, HPV DNA is the primary screening test
    • Start at age 30
    • Screen every 5-10 years
  • As per American Cancer Society
    • Screen between 25-65 years
    • Primary HPV every 5 years is the preferred method of screening
    • Co-testing (HPV + pap smear) every 5 years od pap test alone very 3 years are acceptable options
  • As per Indian Guidelines (FOGSI)
    • In good resource settings
      • Primary HPV is preferred
      • Other options are Co-testing, cytology or VIA (Visual Inspection under acetic acid)
      • Between 25-65 year
      • Every 5 years for primary HPV or co-testing
      • Every 3 years for cytology
    • In Low resource settings
      • VIA or HPV (if affordable and available)
      • Ages 30 – 60; every 5 years.

questions.text: A woman presents to you complaining of a red, watering eye for the past two days with stinging and some photophobia. Her vision has dropped slightly to 20/30. She has a history of diabetes and taking drops for glaucoma, but is otherwise healthy. The most likely cause of her redness is:
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Viral conjunctivitis

This woman probably has a history of POAG (primary open angle glaucoma) if she is on drops. If she were to have an acute angle closure, then her eye would be very painful and the vision would have gotten much worse from corneal oedema. Diabetic retinopathy is usually a background finding of leaky vessels in the retina and doesn’t create this picture. She merits a full eye exam, but her symptoms are consistent with “pink eye” with viral conjunctivitis being the most common cause in an adult. The correct answer is therefore, B.

choices.text: Phase zero clinical trials are conducted in healthy volunteers
Phase zero clinical trials are designed to test the efficacy of a new drug
Phase zero clinical trials typically involve large groups of participants
Phase zero clinical trials are sometimes referred to as therapeutic trials

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding phase zero clinical trials?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Phase zero clinical trials are conducted in healthy volunteers

  • Phase zero clinical trials are conducted in healthy volunteers: This statement is true. Phase zero clinical trials, also known as exploratory trials or human micro-dosing studies, involve administering a small dose of a drug to a small number of healthy volunteers to determine how the drug is metabolized and how it interacts with the body.
  • Phase zero clinical trials are designed to test the efficacy of a new drug: This statement is false. Phase zero clinical trials are not designed to test the efficacy of a new drug. Instead, they are designed to provide preliminary information on the pharmacokinetics of a drug, as well as to help researchers make informed decisions about whether to proceed with further clinical trials.
  • Phase zero clinical trials typically involve large groups of participants: This statement is false. Phase zero clinical trials typically involve a small number of participants. The goal is to minimize risk to the participants and to provide preliminary data on the pharmacokinetics of the drug.
  • Phase zero clinical trials are sometimes referred to as therapeutic trials: This statement is false. Phase zero clinical trials are not therapeutic trials because they do not involve administering a therapeutic dose of the drug. Instead, they involve administering a sub-therapeutic dose of the drug to healthy volunteers to determine how the drug is metabolized and how it interacts with the body.

choices.text: Bipartite patella; X ray of other knee

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presents to the clinic with a complaint of knee pain. The physician orders an X-ray of the affected knee, which is as shown in the image below. Identify the true statement regarding this condition from the options given below?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Bipartite patella; X ray of other knee

  • A bipartite patella is a condition where the patella is made up of two separate bones instead of one. It occurs when the patella fails to fuse properly during development, leading to a bipartite appearance. This condition is typically asymptomatic and may go unnoticed for many years. However, in some cases, it can cause pain, swelling, or discomfort, especially during physical activity.
  • The X-ray of opposite knee must be taken as the condition is bilateral in 50% of cases and this condition is more common in males than females.

  • Management of bipartite patella usually involves conservative measures to alleviate symptoms. These measures may include rest, ice, and physical therapy to strengthen the Quadriceps muscles surrounding the knee and reduce stress on the patella. In more severe cases, a brace may be recommended to provide additional support and reduce stress on the patella. Pain medications and anti-inflammatory drugs may also be prescribed to relieve pain and reduce inflammation.
  • If conservative measures fail to provide relief, surgery may be considered. Surgery for bipartite patella typically involves removing the smaller bone fragment and smoothing the joint surface to reduce friction and alleviate pain. In rare cases, surgery may involve fusing the two patellar fragments together to create a single patella.

Overall, the management of bipartite patella is focused on relieving symptoms and improving function. With appropriate treatment, most people with this condition can return to their normal activities without significant limitations.

choices.text: HFNC is contraindicated in patients with respiratory distress
HFNC delivers oxygen at a flow rate of less than 5 L/min
HFNC can provide positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP)
HFNC is only used for short-term oxygen therapy

questions.text: Which of the following statements about high flow nasal cannula (HFNC) is true?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. HFNC can provide positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP)

Option A. HFNC is contraindicated in patients with respiratory distress.

This statement is false. HFNC is actually commonly used in patients with respiratory distress, such as those with acute respiratory failure, as it can help improve oxygenation and reduce work of breathing.

Option B. HFNC delivers oxygen at a flow rate of less than 5 L/min.

This statement is false. HFNC delivers oxygen at a high flow rate, typically ranging from 30 to 60 L/min, which allows for higher fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO2) delivery and can help improve oxygenation.

Option C. HFNC can provide positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP).

This statement is true. HFNC can provide PEEP, which helps prevent alveolar collapse and improves oxygenation by keeping the airways open during expiration.

Option D. HFNC is only used for short-term oxygen therapy.

This statement is false. HFNC can be used for both short-term and long-term oxygen therapy, depending on the patient's needs and underlying condition.

choices.text: Decussation of pyramidal tract

questions.text: A 35-year-old male, diagnosed with squint presented to the ophthalmology department for regular check-up. On examination, marked muscle was found affected. At which level does the nerve supply for the marked structure arise?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Red nucleus

The muscle marked in the given CT image is that of the medial rectus. The medial rectus is supplied by the oculomotor nerve, the nucleus of which is situated at the level of the superior colliculus close to the red nucleus.

choices.text: Skin, superficial, deep fascia and muscles

questions.text: In a degloving injury, which of the following components are stripped off?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Skin + Superficial fascia

  • Degloving is the avulsion of skin and subcutaneous fat from the underlying fascia, muscle or bone. A degloving injury may be open or closed.
  • Closed degloving injuries result from shearing forces, which may occur with motor vehicle collisions. The extent of these injuries is often underappreciated and much of the skin may be non-viable. Disruption of perforating vascular and lymphatic vessels may result in a characteristic haemolymphatic collection between the fascial planes called a Morel-Lavallée lesion.
  • Most surgeons serially excise the degloved skin until punctate dermal bleeding is seen from viable tissue.
  • It may be appropriate to offer primary amputation in cases of severe multi-planar degloving.

choices.text: Mobitz type I, second-degree heart block
Mobitz type II, second-degree heart block

questions.text: You are seeing Mr. Dayalan who is a 24-year-old previously healthy athlete. He is in for his employer-required physical examination. Which of the following rhythms is demonstrated in the figure?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Mobitz type I, second-degree heart block

This is Mobitz type I, second-degree heart block, or Wenckebach heart block. The periodic failure of conduction in Mobitz type I block is characterized by a progressively lengthening PR interval, shortening of the RR interval, and a pause that is less than two times the immediately preceding RR interval on the electrocardiogram (ECG). The ECG complex after the pause exhibits a shorter PR interval than that immediately preceding the pause. This ECG pattern most often arises because of decremental conduction of electrical impulses in the atrioventricular node. This rhythm is usually benign and may be seen in very fit athletes due to high vagal tone.

questions.text: A 30-year-old patient with history of recurrent headache was sent for fundus evaluation. He was found to be having generalised arteriolar attenuation with multiple cotton wool spots and flame shaped haemorrhages in both eyes as shown in the picture given. The most likely cause is?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Hypertensive retinopathy

Hypertensive retinopathy changes are generalised arteriolar constriction, arteriovenous crossing changes, vascular wall changes, flame-shaped haemorrhages, cotton-wool spots, yellow hard exudates, and optic disc oedema.

Diabetic Retinopathy changes are Microaneurysm, Dot & Blot haemorrhages, flame-shaped haemorrhages, yellow hard exudates, cotton-wool spots, Intra Retinal Microvascular Anomalies (IRMA), and Venous Beading in the Non-Proliferative Diabetic Retinopathy (NPDR) stage. In the PDR (Proliferative Diabetic Retinopathy) stage there is evidence of abnormal vascular proliferation as evidenced by NVE (Neovascularisation Elsewhere) NVD (Neovascularisation at Disc), Rubeosis Iridis (Neovascularisation at Iris) and NVG (Neovascular Glaucoma)

Central Retinal Artery Occlusion classically presents with Cherry Red Spot due to pale retina and red reflex at fovea, and cattle trucking in retinal vasculature.

Temporal arteritis with Anterior Ischemic Optic Neuropathy (AION). In the acute phase, AAION produces a pale appearance of the optic nerve head in addition to the oedema. In late phase there is Optic Atrophy.

choices.text: Mast cell degranulation due to cross linking of IgE
Vasculitis due to immune complex formation

questions.text: A patient presented with fever, weight loss and night sweats. He had 2 previous episodes of haemoptysis. His radiograph showed a cavitory lesion in the right lung. Which of the following is the mechanism of cavitation in his lungs?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Delayed type hypersensitivity reaction

The history is suggestive of TB and so, delayed type hypersensitivity reaction is the most appropriate response.

questions.text: Lizy is a 4-year-old girl who has been experiencing developmental delays since birth. She has difficulty with motor skills, including walking and using her hands. She also has trouble communicating with others, has hand wringing movements and often appears to be in her own world. Her parents have taken her to numerous doctors and specialists, but none have been able to provide a definitive diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Rett syndrome

Rett syndrome features:

  • Common in girls
  • Acquired microcephaly
  • MECP2 gene mutation
  • Hand wringing movement
  • Normal at birth followed by developmental regression.

questions.text: A 3-Year-old baby is brought to her paediatrician for a check-up. Stroking the plantar surface of the foot produces a reflex extension of the large toe rather than the expected flexion. The Babinski sign elicited by the physician indicates damage to which of the following?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Pyramidal tracts

Babinski response in a child less than 2 years is not abnormal

  • Upper motor neurons typically refer to corticospinal tract neurons that innervate spinal motor neurons, but they can also include brainstem neurons that control spinal motor neurons. Damage to these neurons initially causes muscles to become weak and flaccid but eventually leads to spasticity, hypertonia (increased resistance to passive movement), hyperactive stretch reflexes, and abnormal extensor plantar response (positive Babinski sign).
  • The Babinski sign is dorsiflexion of the great toe and fanning of the other toes when the lateral aspect of the sole of the foot is scratched.
  • In adults, the normal response to this stimulation is plantar flexion in all the toes. The Babinski sign is of value in the localization of disease processes, but its physiologic significance is unknown. In infants whose corticospinal tracts are not well developed, dorsiflexion of the great toe and fanning of the other toes is the natural response.

DIFFERENCES BETWEEN UPPER AND LOWER MOTOR NEURON INVOLVEMENT

questions.text: Identify the distribution represented by ‘diagram 3’ in the Image below?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Negative skew

  • Box and whisker plot is a convenient way of graphically depicting groups of numerical data through their quartiles
    • Edges of box: 1st and 3rd Quartile
    • Line in Box: 2nd Quartile (Median)
    • Whiskers end: Minimum & Maximum Values

 

  • Outlier: A data point that is located outside the whiskers of the box plot
  • Graph 1 is bilaterally symmetrical, so normal distribution
  • Graph 3 has longer tail towards left, so it’s left (negative) skew
  • Graph 4 has longer tail towards right, so it’s right (positive) skew.

choices.text: Blade of grass deformity

questions.text: A 30-year-old female presents to the clinic with a complaint of hip pain. An X-ray of her proximal femur is ordered to evaluate the underlying cause of the pain. The X-ray reveals a deformity in the proximal femur which is called:
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Shepherd crook deformity

Fibrous Dysplasia is replacement of osseous tissue by fibrous tissue.

In long bones, the fibrous dysplastic lesions have ground-glass appearance.

 

Fig: Mc type is Monostotic

  • Shepherd crook deformity (Looks like shepherds stick which is crooked in shape) bone is replaced by fibrous tissue in fibrous dysplasia.
  • The multiloculated translucent lesion may be surrounded by a sclerotic rim the so called ‘Rind sign’.

Involvement of facial bones may create a leonine appearance (leontiasis ossea).

On biopsy: Chinese Letter Pattern is recognised

Surgical treatment (Curettage + bone grafting) is indicated when significant deformity or pathological fracture occurs or when significant pain exists.

Blade of Grass appearance is seen in Paget’s disease

Chicken wire calcification is seen in Chondroblastoma

Corduroy appearance is x-ray finding in Vertebral Haemangiomas.

questions.text: You are in the operating room and notice the tracing in gray color waveform on the electrocardiogram (ECG) device. The patient is a 65-year-old male undergoing coronary artery bypass graft (CABG) surgery. What does the gray color waveform on the ECG indicate?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Capnography

The grey waveform is of a capnograph.

Capnography measures:

  • Ventilation
  • Circulation
  • Metabolism

questions.text: A patient presented with pallor and cyanosis with following presentation. This condition is most probably due to?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Vitamin B12 deficiency

Knuckle pigmentation is seen in the setting of vitamin B12 deficiency as well as in Addison’s disease. In vitamin B12 deficiency, there is an increased production of oxidants like homocysteine. This leads to relative glutathione depletion leading to the activation of the tyrosinase enzyme. This results in the increased synthesis of melanin leading to pigmentation particularly at knuckles and oral mucosa.

External markers of vitamin B12 deficiency: 

  • Reversible knuckle pigmentation
  • Oral mucosal pigmentation 
  • Recurrent angular stomatitis
  • Cheilitis 
  • Polymorphic cutaneous eruption
  • Grey, thin, dry, and lustreless hair

Incorrect Answers:

Folic acid deficiency results in megaloblastic anaemia whereas Iron deficiency results in hypochromic microcytic anaemia with the hair, skin (pallor), and nail changes (koilonychia).

 

Ref: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC7654476/

questions.text: A young 23-year-old black man presents with the clinical picture shown in the right eye after blunt injury. All of the following are acceptable initial treatments except?
questions.solution:
Ans. D.  Carbonic anhydrase inhibitor pressure drops

For patients with hyphema (blood in the eye), advise them to avoid straining and sleep with their heads elevated to allow the blood to settle. Use steroids to decrease the inflammation and a medium-acting cycloplegic to dilate the eye for comfort and to keep the inflamed iris from “sticking” to the lens underneath. If the pressure is high, you can use pressure drops, but we avoid carbonic anhydrase inhibitors (CAIs) in African Americans as it induces RBC sickling in sickle-cell patients.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman has noted painless enlargement of her neck for the past month. On physical examination, she has diffuse, symmetrical thyroid enlargement without tenderness on palpation. Laboratory studies show her serum TSH is elevated but serum thyroxine is lower side of normal limits. Her microscopic examination is shown here. Which of the following laboratory test findings is she most likely to have?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. High anti-thyroid peroxidase antibody titre

The lymphoid follicles are present in the thyroid. Hashimoto thyroiditis is one of the most common causes for hypothyroidism in adults. Early in the course of the disease the chronic inflammation predominates followed later by fibrosis.

questions.text: Lila is a 4-year-old girl who was recently hospitalized for meningitis. She received treatment and was discharged from the hospital, but her parents noticed that she was not responding to sounds and seemed to be having trouble hearing. What could be the possible diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Sensorineural deafness

One of the common sequelae of meningitis is sensorineural hearing loss. Whenever you discharge a patient of meningitis, always get ENT opinion done.

questions.text: A 23-year-old medical student presents to the surgery emergency department after cutting her wrist with a blade. After receiving first aid, the resident notices multiple healed cut marks on her wrist. Upon psychiatry referral, the patient informs the resident that she cut herself because she was feeling very angry at her boyfriend who spent the entire evening watching an IPL match rather than calling her. She also mentions that she has never been in a relationship with a guy for more than 2 months and believes that all men are horrible, while women are the best. What is the most likely diagnosis for this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Borderline Personality Disorder

A pattern of unstable interpersonal relationships, self-harming behaviour, black-and-white thinking about men and women are all consistent with a diagnosis of Borderline Personality Disorder.

Option A. Histrionic Personality Disorder is characterized by exaggerated emotions and attention-seeking behaviour.

Option C. Narcissistic Personality Disorder is characterized by excessive self-importance (grandiose), fantasies of unlimited success and power and poor tolerance to criticism

Option D. Dependent Personality Disorder is characterized by an excessive need to be taken care of, submissive behaviour, and a fear of separation.

questions.text: A 32-year-old male patient with a history of ulcerative colitis presents to the emergency department complaining of abdominal pain, distention, and fever. He reports having bloody diarrhoea and has been using mesalamine and prednisone to manage his condition. On physical examination, his abdomen is tender and distended, and bowel sounds are absent. Laboratory tests indicate leucocytosis and electrolyte imbalances. An erect abdominal X-ray was taken as shown. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Toxic megacolon

  • Dilated transverse and descending colon, with loss of characteristic haustrations is suggestive of toxic megacolon. The upper limit of normal bowel diameter for small bowel is 3 cm, for large bowel 6 cm and for cecum 9 cm.
  • The most widely used criteria for the clinical diagnosis of toxic megacolon are:

Radiographic evidence of colonic distension PLUS at least three of the following:

  • Fever > 38°C
  • Heart rate > 120/min
  • Neutrophilic leucocytosis >10,500/μL
  • Anaemia.

questions.text: A patient presents to the outpatient department with a satellite skin lesion. On examination, he has one hypopigmented lesion and one thickened nerve. Images of two blister packs are given below. The treatment best suited for this patient would be?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Packet 2 for 6 months

The treatment best suited for this patient, as per the WHO, would be packet 2 for 6 months. One thickened nerve and one hypopigmented satellite skin lesion in a clinical setting point to paucibacillary (PB) leprosy. Paucibacillary leprosy is treated with rifampicin, clofazimine, and dapsone, all of which are found in the pink blister packet, over the course of six months.

World Health Organisation (WHO)

Treatment for both paucibacillary and multibacillary leprosy involves multidrug therapy. It includes dapsone, clofazimine, and rifampicin. When treating multibacillary leprosy, the same regimen is followed for 12 months as opposed to 6 months when treating paucibacillary leprosy.

choices.text: Superior pole of patella, impinging during flexion
Superior pole of patella, impinging during extension
Inferior pole of patella, impinging during flexion
Inferior pole of patella, impinging during extension

questions.text: A 45-year-old female patient who underwent a total knee replacement surgery two years ago complains of pain and a clicking sensation in her knee joint while extending it. Based on these symptoms, which of the following is true regarding the scar tissue in patellar clunk syndrome?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Superior pole of patella, impinging during extension

Patellar clunk syndrome (PCS) occasionally occurs after posterior stabilized total knee replacement (PS-TKR), and is characterized by a painful palpable audible clunk of the patella when the knee moves from flexion to extension. It has been classically attributed to the formation of fibrous nodule at the junction of the proximal pole of the patella and the undersurface of the distal quadriceps tendon.

This can become entrapped in the intercondylar notch of the femoral prosthesis and cause the knee to clunk at 30-45 degrees of knee flexion while the patient actively extends the knee.

questions.text: Identify the device shown in the image below?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Automated External Defibrillator

An automated external defibrillator (AED) is a portable electronic device that automatically diagnoses the life-threatening cardiac arrhythmias of ventricular fibrillation (VF) and pulseless ventricular tachycardia, and is able to treat them through defibrillation, the application of electricity which stops the arrhythmia, allowing the heart to re-establish an effective rhythm.

It is used in patients who are more than eight years old or those weighing more than 25 kgs.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presented with unilateral hearing loss. Oto-endoscopic picture is shown below. Rinne’s test was negative and Weber’s test was lateralised to the same ear. Which view should be examined next in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. D.

Any elderly patient presenting with unilateral hearing loss showing serous otitis media, should be suspected of nasopharyngeal carcinoma. Fossa of rosenmuller (white arrow in option d) is the most common site of origin. So, nasopharyngeal examination should be done first. Any growth in the fossa of rosenmuller will close the eustachian tube and blocks the drainage of middle ear and the secretions get collected in the middle ear leading to serous otitis media that further causes conductive hearing loss.

questions.text: Which of the following chelating agents is recommended for acute lead poisoning with signs of encephalopathy?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Dimercaprol + Calcium EDTA

  • Succimer is the agent of choice for asymptomatic, mild Lead poisoning (45-70 mcg/dL in children, 70-100 mcg/dL in adults) because it is available PO and has a low side effect profile.
  • For severe toxicity with signs of encephalopathy, Dimercaprol (previously known as BAL; British Anti-Lewisite) is given IM followed by Calcium EDTA via continuous infusion to combine to chelate Lead from the brain and body, respectively.

Dosages are as follows:
Succimer: 10 mg/kg PO Q 8H x 5 days, followed by 10 mg/kg Q 12H for 14 days
Dimercaprol: 4 mg/kg IM Q 4H x 5 days
Calcium EDTA: 1500 mg/m2 IV Q 24H via continuous infusion x 5 days (started 4 hours after Dimercaprol).

questions.text:
Three patients are brought to casualty after motor-vehicle accident with head injury.Their GCS assessment is as below:

 

Patient A: E3V3M3

Patient B: E2V4M3

Patient C: E2V3M4

Who amongst them has the best prognosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Patient C

Severity of head injury is classified according to the post-resuscitation Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS), as it is the GCS score, and in particular the motor score, that is the best predictor of neurological outcome.

questions.text: Emily is a 10-year-old girl who has been experiencing headaches, vomiting, and vision problems. Her headache starts early in the morning and worsens on lying down. After several visits to her paediatrician, she is referred to a neurologist and undergoes imaging tests. What is the possible diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Cranioharyngioma

  1. Migraine headache improves on lying down
  2. The key feature of increased intracranial pressure is the headache that worsens on lying down
  3. So, it is important to rule out space-occupying lesion
  4. Cranipharyngioma: benign brain tumor that begins near the pituitary gland

questions.text: A 65-year-old male with a history of chronic kidney disease presents to the emergency department with complaints of muscle weakness, nausea, and abdominal cramping. Laboratory testing shows that the patient has hyperkalaemia, with a serum potassium level of 6.5 mEq/L. The patient's medications are reviewed, and it is discovered that he has been taking several drugs for his cardiac conditions and hypertension. Upon further evaluation, it is determined that one of these drugs may be contributing to the patient's hyperkalaemia. Which of the following drugs should be stopped in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Telmisartan

  • Telmisartan is an angiotensin II receptor blocker (ARB) used in the treatment of hypertension and can cause hyperkalaemia as a side effect.
  • Hydrochlorothiazide is a thiazide diuretic and Furosemide is a loop diuretic, these can cause hypokalaemia but not hyperkalaemia.
  • Amlodipine is a calcium channel blocker that does not typically cause electrolyte imbalances.

Note: Telmisartan in addition to its beneficial effect on nephropathy can also reverse insulin resistance due to its PPAR-gamma agonistic activity.

questions.text:
A medical student have given a topic to present in class. The topic given to you was excitation-contraction coupling. It is a process in which muscle cells are stimulated to contract and it is followed by muscle cell relaxation. It involves the following events:

  1. Action potential
  2. Calcium release into the cytoplasm
  3. Cross-bridge cycling
  4. Cytoplasmic calcium removal
  5. Depolarization of T tubules

Which of the following options lists the correct sequence of events for excitation-contraction coupling in skeletal muscle tissue?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. 1, 5, 2, 3, 4

Action potential comes and causes Depolarization of T-tubules which causes calcium release into the cytoplasm. Free calcium binds to troponin C on actin filaments and causes a conformational change and exposes a site on the actin molecule that binds to the myosin head which results in ATP hydrolysis and produces crossbridge cycling. And producing a contraction. Finally, calcium is re-sequestrated back into ER to allow relaxation to occur.

choices.text: It’s usually seen in smaller samples only

questions.text: What is not true about the given graph?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. It’s usually seen in smaller samples only

Normal (Gaussian/ Standard) distribution

  • Is Bilaterally symmetrical, bell-shaped curve
  • Mean ± 1SD (μ ± 1σ) covers 68.3% values
  • Mean ± 2SD (μ ± 2σ) covers 95.4% values
  • Mean ± 3SD (μ ± 3σ) covers 99.7% values
  • Mean, median and mode coincide
  • It’s usually seen in large populations or samples.

 

Ref. Park 27/e p977

questions.text: Fibres from the marked structure end in which of the following areas of the thalamus?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Anterior nucleus

The structure marked in the above image is mamillary body and the fibres from the mammillary body that ends in the anterior nucleus of the thalamus.

The mammillary bodies are two small hemispherical, pea-sized eminences, lying side by side, forming the floor of the third ventricle. The fibres from medial mammillary nucleus project to the anterior nucleus of the thalamus.

The anterior thalamic nuclei have 3 subdivisions: anteroventral nucleus, anteromedial nucleus, and anterodorsal nucleus.

• Major input: Mamillothalamic tract from the mammillary nuclei of the hypothalamus

• Major cortical output: Anterior limbic area, cingulate, and the parahippocampal gyrus

• Major function:

  • Regulation of alertness and attention
  • Acquisition of memory

choices.text: Hypo alpha lipoproteinemia
Familial alpha Lipoprotein deficiency
Hyper alpha lipoproteinemia

questions.text: A 45 years old man, who has a  history of dyslipidaemia and  coronary artery diseases presents with recurrent episodes of neuropathy. Oral examination reveal finding as shown in picture. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Tangier Disease                            

  • Defects in ABCA1, an ATP-binding cassette (ABC) protein involved in transferring cellular cholesterol to HDL.
  • So, plasma HDL is low and alpha band is absent in electrophoresis.
  • Cholesterol esters are accumulated in tissues.
  • Clinical features: Large orange yellow tonsils, muscle atrophy, recurrent peripheral neuropathies and atherosclerosis. These are the hallmark features.

Incorrect answers:

Option A. Hypo alpha lipoproteinemia: Here serum HDL is decreased → High risk for coronary artery diseases.

Option C. Familial alpha Lipoprotein deficiency: Have ↓↓ HDL and A-l, Normal- Cholesterol and TAG → Increased risk of coronary artery diseases.

Option D. Hyper alpha lipoproteinemia: Increased HDL and is a rare condition apparently beneficial to health.

 

 

Ref: Lippincott 7/e, Pg. 236

choices.text: Weber-Ferguson incision is used during surgical excision of this tumour
Biopsy should be done before performing surgery to know its nature
It affects only adolescent males
Proptosis can be caused by the intra-orbital extension of this tumour

questions.text: A 15-year-old adolescent male presented with repeated episodes of profuse epistaxis and following features were seen. Identify the false statement regarding this condition:
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Biopsy should be done before performing surgery to know its nature

Most common benign tumour of nasopharynx. Arises from sphenopalatine foramen. Exclusive in adolescent males. Patient presents with profuse epistaxis and nasal obstruction. The contractile muscular part of blood vessels is absent which makes the bleeding uncontrollable. On examination, red and fleshy mass seen in nasal cavity. It can cause splaying of nasal bones leading to broadening of nasal bridge. As Eustachian tube obstruction occurs, serous otitis media can occur and patient can present with hearing loss (conductive type). The tumour can spread laterally into pterygopalatine fossa also and can cause pressure over posterior wall of maxillary sinus, this causes it’s bowing anteriorly, this is called as ‘Holman-Miller sign or Antral sign,’ can be seen on CT scan. It can also extend into orbit through inferior orbital fissure causing proptosis. It can also spread into infratemporal fossa through pterygomaxillary fissure and can appear as cheek swelling. Even intracranial extension can occur. All the features like nasal bridge broadening, proptosis and cheek swelling gives rise to ‘frog face deformity.’ Biopsy is absolutely contra-indicated (as it is a vascular tumour and once bleeding starts due to forceps injury, then it will be difficult to control it). Rx is mainly surgical excision by various approaches depending upon extension.

questions.text: A 15-year-old male presents to emergency department in a comatose state. He was found in this state by his friend in the schoolyard. His friend confesses that the patient has been depressed over the past several days. His initial labs reveal hypocalcaemia and a severe metabolic acidosis. The urine shows calcium oxalate crystals. What was the toxin ingested?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Ethylene Glycol

  • This patient suffers from ethylene glycol ingestion.
  • The metabolites of ethylene glycol, including glycolaldehyde, glycolic acid and oxalate are toxic and result in severe metabolic acidosis.
  • There are three stages of toxicity:
    • The first stage causes CNS manifestations, metabolic acidosis, hypertension, hypocalcaemia, and leucocytosis.
    • The second stage includes coma and cardiopulmonary compromise.
    • The third stage occurs at 24-72 hours and includes renal failure.
  • Urinalysis usually reveals oxalate crystals.
  • In the case of antifreeze ingestion, the urine will fluoresce under Woods’ lamp examination.

questions.text: Max is a 6-month-old boy who has been experiencing brief, sudden contractions that result in flexion of his body. His parents notice that these spasms occur in clusters throughout the day and are becoming more frequent. Max also seems to be experiencing developmental regression, as he has stopped babbling and seems to have difficulty with basic motor skills. Identify the condition he is suffering from?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Infantile spasms

Infantile spasms + Mental retardation (intellectual disability) + Hyperarrythmias in EEG = Wast Syndrome

Drug of choice for infantile spasms in West Syndrome is ACTH and drug of choice for infantile spasms in tuberous sclerosis is Vigabatrin

choices.text: Pain on passive stretch

questions.text: Which of the following findings appear last in compartment syndrome?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Pulselessness

  • Pulselessness is a late sign is compartment syndrome.
  • Fractures of the elbow, forearm, proximal third of the tibia, and multiple fractures of the hand and foot are at increased risk of developing acute compartment syndrome. Other high-risk injuries are crush injuries and circumferential burns.
  • The classic features of ischemia in acute compartment syndrome include the 5 P's:
  • Pain: Pain is the first symptom of acute compartment syndrome. Ischemic muscle groups have an increased sensitivity to touch. On passive stretching of the muscles, severe pain can be elicited.
  • Paraesthesia: Paraesthesia and hypoesthesia may be noted due to compression of nerves traversing the affected compartment. They are the first signs of nerve ischemia.
  • Pallor: Pallor of the skin may not always be seen as the ischemia occurs at the capillary level.
  • Paralysis: Paralysis of muscle groups affected in that compartment.
  • Pulselessness: The absence of distal pulses. The presence or absence of a palpable arterial pulse may not accurately indicate relative tissue pressure or predict the risk for compartment syndrome. In some patients, a pulse is still present, even in a severely compromised extremity.

Diagnosis:

  • Split catheter to measure intra-compartmental pressure introduced into the compartment.
  • The difference between diastolic pressure and compartment pressure is known as differential pressure (AP). If the differential pressure (AP) is less than 30 mm Hg (4.00 kilopascals), immediate compartment decompression is indicated.

Treatment:

  • Prompt decompression of the affected compartment is done.
  • All the dressings, bandages, and cast on the affected limb are removed and the limb is nursed flat.
  • Fasciotomy is done if the differential pressure is less than 30 mm Hg. Wounds are left open and after 2 days if there is necrosis debridement is done. If the wounds are healthy it can be sutured without tension or skin grafting can be done.

questions.text: A 75-year-old male presented with history of frequency, hesitancy & urgency for urination. He was on medication of Tamsulosin & Finasteride combination. Now Trans Urethral Resection of Prostate (TURP) surgery was recommended by physician. What is the volume of the prostate in normal adult males?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. 20cc

The volume of the prostate in normal adult males is 20cc.

Prostate is an accessory glandular tissue embedded in the fibromuscular stroma. It usually weighs 8 grams in the young adults and its weight ranges from 40-150 grams in men aged >50 years.

The prostate gland is situated in the lesser pelvis and surrounds the prostatic urethra which extends from bladder base to the membranous urethra. Pubic symphysis and pubic arch lie anteriorly to the prostate whereas rectourethralis and rectal ampulla lie posteriorly to it.

questions.text: A 25-year-old female presented with a painless enlargement in the midline of her neck. Her TSH was 6.5 mIU/ml. The histology of the tissue is as follows. How will you diagnose this case?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Chronic lymphocytic thyroiditis

Hashimoto’s thyroiditis/Chronic lymphocytic thyroiditis is an autoimmune disease that results in the destruction of the thyroid gland and gradual and progressive thyroid failure.

On HPE, Hashimoto’s thyroiditis presents with the following features:

  • Follicular destruction
  • Reduced colloid with increased interstitial connective tissue
  • Small lymphocyte and plasma cell infiltration
  • A well-developed germinal centre maybe seen
  • Hurthle cells that have abundant eosinophilic granular cytoplasm lining the follicles.

questions.text: Your 48-year-old patient presents with complaints of worsening menorrhagia. She has no other medical problems. Three-dimensional sonographic evaluation reveals the findings as shown below. All EXCEPT which of the following are suitable choices for medical treatment in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Levonorgestrel-releasing intrauterine system (LNGIUS)

  • This is a large submucosal fibroid
  • LNG-IUS (Mirena) cannot be used in a uterus which is anatomically distorted.
  • Medical Management of Fibroids includes:
    • Non hormonal:
      • NSAID
      • Anti-fibrinolytics
    • Hormonal:
      • Combined OCPS
      • GnRH agonist
      • DMPA
      • SPRMs (Mifepristone, Ulipristal)
      • Ormeloxifene
      • GnRH antagonist
  • Contraindications to Mirena:
    • Unexplained uterine or vaginal bleeding
    • Post abortal sepsis
    • Puerperal sepsis
    • Endometrial cancer
    • Cervical cancer
    • Gestational trophoblastic neoplasia
    • Current Pelvic inflammatory disease
    • Genital Tuberculosis
    • Large fibroid distorting the uterine cavity
    • Mullerian anomalies distorting the uterine cavity

 

 

Ref: Page no. 272, Shaw’s Textbook of Gynaecology, 16th edition

Thrombosis depends on Thromboxane A2

questions.text:
Which of the following statements is/are true regarding anti-tubercular drugs?

  1. Isoniazid inhibits mycolic acid synthesis in the cell wall of Mycobacterium tuberculosis.
  2. Rifampicin is primarily used for the treatment of active tuberculosis and can cause liver toxicity and flu-like symptoms.
  3. Bedaquiline is a second-line anti-tubercular drug that can cause QT prolongation and requires cardiac monitoring.
  4. Pretomanid is primarily used as a monotherapy for the treatment of tuberculosis.
questions.solution:
Ans. B. 1, 2 and 3 are correct

  • Option 1 is true: Isoniazid is a first-line anti-tubercular drug that works by inhibiting the synthesis of mycolic acid in the cell wall of Mycobacterium tuberculosis, which is essential for its survival. This results in the destruction of the bacteria and is effective in the treatment of both active and latent tuberculosis.
  • Option 2 is true: Rifampicin is a first-line anti-tubercular drug that is primarily used in the treatment of active tuberculosis. Rifampicin can cause liver toxicity as well as flu-like symptoms such as fever, chills, and muscle pain. Routine monitoring of liver function tests is recommended during treatment with rifampicin.
  • Option 3 is true: Bedaquiline is a newer second-line anti-tubercular drug that is used in the treatment of drug-resistant tuberculosis. It can cause QT prolongation, a heart rhythm abnormality, and requires cardiac monitoring during treatment.
  • Option 4 is incorrect: Pretomanid is typically used in combination with other anti-tubercular drugs for the treatment of drug-resistant tuberculosis, rather than as a monotherapy. Pretomanid is often used in combination with bedaquiline and linezolid for the treatment of drug-resistant tuberculosis.

questions.text: In recent years, incidence of noncommunicable diseases like diabetes and hypertension have increased. This is an example of:
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Secular trend

Long-Term Fluctuations [Secular Trends]

  • Implies changes in occurrence of a disease (progressive increase or decrease) over a long period of time, generally several years or decades
  • Communicable diseases (Poliomyelitis, Diphtheria, Pertussis) are reducing in India in past few decades
  • Non-communicable diseases (Diabetes, Hypertension, Obesity) are increasing in India in past few decades.

 

 

 

Ref. Park 27/e, p. 74

questions.text: Which structure from the options given below is supplied by the nerve that arises from the marked area in the image?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Risorius

Risorius is supplied by the facial nerve which causes the elevation marked. The image shows the floor of the fourth ventricle and the facial colliculus is marked.

The facial colliculus is present in the superior part of floor of 4th ventricle, which presents as a small elevation produced by the root of the facial nerve winding around the nucleus of the abducens nerve. Columns are formed by groups of facial neurones, which innervate individual muscles and give branches of the facial nerve. Dorsal neurones innervate muscles in the scalp and upper face and ventral neurons supply the lower facial musculature.    

Other options:

Option A. Lateral rectus is an extraocular muscle that arises from the lateral part of the common tendinous ring. It is innervated by the abducens nerve.

Option B. Superior oblique is an extraocular muscle that arises from the body of the sphenoid. It is innervated by the trochlear nerve.

Option D. Levator palpebrae superiors is an extraocular muscle that arises from the lesser wing of sphenoid. It is innervated by the oculomotor nerve.

choices.text: Branched chain ketoacid dehydrogenase
Methyl malonyl CoA mutase

questions.text: An 8-year-old child developed modest mental retardation and was brought to a physician. She had a history of vomiting, lethargy, convulsions, and hypertonia during her first week of life. Lab examination reported increased levels of Leucine, isoleucine, and valine in blood and urine. Which one of the following enzymes does this child lack?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Branched chain ketoacid dehydrogenase             

  • Branched chain amino acids include Valine, leucine, and isoleucine.
  • Deficiency of the branched chain ketoacid dehydrogenase results in maple syrup urine disease which leads to accumulation of branched chain ketoacids in blood, urine, and tissues.
  • The urine has the maple syrup odour with development of metabolic acidosis. 
  • Early diagnosis is important to reduce the occurrence of irreversible mental retardation.
  • Treatment: Diet with limited amounts of these amino acids.

Incorrect answers:

Option B. Cystathionine synthase: Congenital homocystinuria, Clinical features- Mental retardation, Ectopia lentis, Thrombosis and Charlie Chaplin gait.

Option C. Ornithine transcarbamoylase: The only urea cycle disorder with X-linked trait. Clinical features- Hyperammonaemia, elevated levels of ammonia are associated with high glutamine levels in CSF and blood in the affected child. Mothers also have hyperammonaemia and an aversion to high protein diet.

Option D. Methylmalonyl CoA mutase: Methylmalonic Aciduria. Clinical features- MR, ketosis, hypotonia, Blood-methyl malonic acid is elevated and in urine -methyl maIonic acid and ketone bodies are seen. Treatment –Vitamin B12.

 

 

Ref: Harper 30/e, p. 309-311

choices.text: Occurs due to gradual slowing of blood flow and desiccation of tissues
Has superadded putrefaction
The black colour is due to iron sulphide formation from hemoglobin

questions.text: A poorly controlled diabetic patient presented with the following picture. There was crepitus on palpation. All the following statements are true about this condition except?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Occurs due to gradual slowing of blood flow and desiccation of tissues

This is a case of wet gangrene. Gradual slowing of blood flow and dessication is seen in dry gangrene.

Gangrene refers to the death of macroscopic portions of tissue, which turns black because of the breakdown of haemoglobin and the formation of iron sulphide. It usually affects the most distal part of a limb because of arterial obstruction (from thrombosis, embolus or arteritis).

  • Dry gangrene occurs when the tissues are desiccated by gradual slowing of the blood stream; it is typically the result of atheromatous occlusion of arteries. 
  • Wet gangrene occurs when superadded infection and putrefaction are present. Crepitus may be palpated as a result of infection by gas-forming organisms, commonly in diabetic foot problems, and should be considered a surgical emergency with urgent tissue debridement or amputation required.

questions.text: An elderly smoker had several episodes of hemoptysis in the past two weeks along with fatigue, headache, nausea, and anorexia. A chest radiograph shows an ill-defined hilar mass and the transbronchial lung biopsy is performed. The microscopic appearance is shown. Which of the following laboratory test findings is most likely to be present in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Increased risk of cavitation

Presence of keratin pearls is seen with squamous cell cancer. So, the answer is Increased risk of cavitation.

questions.text: A 70-year-old male patient with a history of heart failure and atrial fibrillation has been taking digoxin for several months. He was recently started on a new medication for hypertension. He presents to the clinic with symptoms of nausea, vomiting, and visual disturbances. Which of the following drugs is most likely responsible for these symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Hydrochlorothiazide

  • Symptoms of digoxin toxicity include nausea, vomiting, loss of appetite, and visual disturbances. Other symptoms can include dizziness, confusion, and changes in heart rate or rhythm. Hydrochlorothiazide can cause electrolyte abnormalities such as hypokalaemia, which can increase the risk of digoxin toxicity.
  • Metformin is an oral antidiabetic medication that does not interact with digoxin.
  • Lisinopril is an angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitor and amlodipine is a calcium channel blocker, both of which do not interact with digoxin.

choices.text: Sodium outflow in thick ascending limb
Water outflow in thin descending limb
Sodium outflow in thin ascending limb
Flow of tubular fluid from PCT to DCT

questions.text: All of the following are components responsible for the counter current mechanism in the kidney except?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Flow of tubular fluid from PCT to DCT

PCT to DCT is not a component of the counter current mechanism.

Counter current system has two divisions:

  1. Counter current multiplier formed by loop of Henle & Medullary CD
  2. Counter current exchanger formed by vasa recta.

The major factors that contribute to the build-up of solute concentration into the renal medulla are as follows:

  1.  Ascending limb of loop of Henle – Thick portion (Active transport) and Thin portion (Passive transport) of sodium ions and co-transport of potassium, chloride, and other ions into the medullary interstitium
  2. Collecting ducts – Active transport of ions into the medullary interstitium
  3. Inner medullary collecting ducts – Facilitated diffusion of large amounts of urea into the medullary interstitium

Note: The thin ascending limbs of juxtamedullary nephrons are permeable to Na+ and Cl- and hence, do contribute passively to counter current multiplication.

questions.text:
Which of the following immunization is done in elderly?

1 – Rota virus vaccine

2 – Meningococcal vaccine

3 – Diphtheria toxoid

4 – Varicella Zoster vaccine

Mark the correct combination.
questions.solution:
Ans. D. 2, 4

CDC GUIDELINES FOR IMMUNIZATION OF OLDER PEOPLE

  • Influenza intramuscular inactivated vaccine
  • Pneumococcal vaccine once
  • Tetanus-diphtheria toxoid (Td) booster every 10 years
  • In selected patients aged 60 years or more: Herpes zoster (shingles), Hepatitis A, Hepatitis B, Meningococcal disease, Varicella, MMR, Yellow fever vaccine (for travellers)

 

 

Ref: Immunization in Older Adults, Issue 21, 2007

questions.text: Which is not a branch of Anaesthetist’s artery?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Mental

Facial artery is also known as anaesthetist’s artery.

Mental is not a branch of the facial artery but the branch of the maxillary artery in the face.

The first part of the maxillary artery gives rise to the mental artery as a terminal branch of the inferior alveolar artery.

The facial artery is a branch of the external carotid artery which arises in the carotid triangle, above the origin of the lingual artery. It runs upwards in the neck and curves around the anteroinferior border of the masseter to enter the face.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male patient with a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) is on theophylline therapy. He presents to the emergency department with symptoms of nausea, vomiting, and tremors. On examination, he has a heart rate of 110 beats per minute and a serum theophylline level of 30 mg/L (normal range 5-15 mg/L). Which of the following drugs is most likely responsible for the patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Clarithromycin

  • Clarithromycin can interact with theophylline by inhibiting its metabolism, leading to an increase in serum concentration and an increased risk of toxicity.
  • Symptoms of theophylline toxicity include nausea, vomiting, tremors, seizures, and tachycardia. In severe cases, theophylline toxicity can lead to cardiac arrhythmias and seizures.
  • Other drugs that can interact with theophylline include ciprofloxacin, erythromycin, and fluvoxamine.

choices.text: Unopposed inward recoil will be there
Intra thorax pressure will be zero
Only A and B are true

questions.text: A 32-year-old man met with a bike accident and handle of bike hit him badly that when he was brought to the hospital. Doctors find out that there is puncture in parietal pleura membrane. True about this condition is?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Only A and B are true

The parietal pleura membrane has been ruptured already, so, it will behave like an open cavity and intra thorax pressure will be zero and there will be unopposed inward recoil which will lead to collapsing of lung. So, option A and B are true.

Option C is not correct because the lungs will be collapsed.

Therefore, option D is answer.

choices.text: If mother had reported when Shyam got infection, Ram could have been vaccinated

questions.text: A women had two children named Ram and Shyam. One day, Shyam had Measles with fever and rash. After a few days, Ram developed the same symptoms. He was reported to the sub-centre. Which of the following is incorrect?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Ram is the index case

In the given question,

  • First Shyam got Measles, so Shyam is the Primary case for the family
  • After few days, Ram developed the same symptoms, So Ram is the Secondary case
  • To be effective, Measles vaccine must be given to contacts within 3 days of exposure. So, if mother had reported when Shyam got infection, Ram could have been vaccinated.

 

 

Ref: Park 27/e, p. 167

questions.text: Which of the following structures passing via jugular foramen has a separate canal?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Glossopharyngeal nerve

2nd largest foramen of skull: Jugular foramen

Largest foramen of skull: foramen magna

The glossopharyngeal nerve passing through the jugular foramen has a separate canal.

The jugular foramen is formed by the occipital bone and the petrous part of the temporal bone. The spinal accessory nerve and vagus nerve also pass through this foramen.

The glossopharyngeal nerve leaves the skull through the anteromedial part of the jugular foramen in a separate dural sheath.

The branches of the nerve are tympanic, carotid, pharyngeal, muscular, tonsillar and lingual branches.

Infection, malignancy and postoperative inflammation of the tonsil and tonsillar fossa will cause referred pain in the ear. This is conducted through the tympanic branch of the glossopharyngeal nerve.

Pharyngeal branches of the glossopharyngeal nerve and vagus nerve form the pharyngeal plexus of nerves. These plexes mainly supply the pharynx. It also has contributions from the superior cervical ganglion.

Nerve supply by the pharyngeal branch of the vagus nerve are:

  • All the muscles of the soft palate (except tensor veli palatini - supplied by mandibular division of the trigeminal nerve)
  • All the muscles of the pharynx (except stylopharyngeus - supplied by the glossopharyngeal nerve)

questions.text: Which of the following anticancer drugs act at the target shown in figure?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Ribociclib

‘Ciclib’ are CDK4/6 inhibitors

  • Ribociclib is a selective inhibitor of cyclin-dependent kinases 4 and 6 (CDK4/6), which are enzymes that play a critical role in cell cycle progression. These kinases promote cell proliferation by phosphorylating and inactivating the retinoblastoma protein (Rb), which in turn allows the cell to pass through the G1 checkpoint and enter S phase of the cell cycle.
  • Inhibition of CDK4/6 by Ribociclib results in cell cycle arrest in the G1 phase, leading to inhibition of cell proliferation. This mechanism of action is particularly relevant in cancer cells, which often have aberrant regulation of the cell cycle and increased reliance on CDK4/6 activity to drive proliferation.
  • Ribociclib is approved for use in combination with other therapies for the treatment of estrogen receptor-positive, human epidermal growth factor receptor 2-negative (HR+/HER2-) advanced or metastatic breast cancer.
  • Erlotinib: Erlotinib is a tyrosine kinase inhibitor that targets the epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR) pathway. It works by blocking the activity of the EGFR protein, which is often overexpressed in certain types of cancer cells and contributes to tumour growth and spread. Erlotinib is primarily used to treat non-small cell lung cancer and pancreatic cancer.
  • Dabrafenib: Dabrafenib is a selective inhibitor of the BRAF protein, which is a key component of the MAP kinase signalling pathway. This pathway is frequently mutated in certain types of cancer, including melanoma, and drives tumour growth and survival. Dabrafenib is used to treat advanced melanoma with BRAF V600E or V600K mutations
  • Nilotinib: Nilotinib is a tyrosine kinase inhibitor that targets the BCR-ABL protein, which is a fusion protein that drives the growth of chronic myelogenous leukaemia (CML) cells. It works by blocking the activity of the BCR-ABL protein, leading to inhibition of cell proliferation and induction of cell death. Nilotinib is taken orally and is primarily used to treat CML.

choices.text: Non-ionic calcium is most important stimulus for PTH secretion
Mg stimulates PTH secretion in the same way as Ca
Hypercalcemia in cancer patients is due to parathormone related protein.
Parathyroid senses calcium through calcium sensing receptor

questions.text: Which of the following is false regarding PTH secretion?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Non-ionic calcium is most important stimulus for PTH secretion

  • Circulating ionized calcium acts directly on the parathyroid glands in a negative feedback fashion to regulate the secretion of PTH. The key to this regulation is a cell membrane Ca2+ sensing receptor, CaR.
  • Activation of this G-protein coupled receptor leads to phosphoinositide turnover in many tissues. In the parathyroid, its activation inhibits PTH secretion.
  • In this way, when the plasma Ca2+ level is high, PTH secretion is inhibited and the Ca2+ is deposited in the bones. When it is low, secretion is increased and Ca2+ is mobilized from the bones.
  • Mg2+ works in the similar fashion and when it is low, PTH secretion is increased
  • Parathyroid hormone-related protein (or PTHrP) is a protein member of the parathyroid hormone family. It is occasionally secreted by cancer cells (breast cancer, certain types of lung cancer including squamous cell carcinoma).
  • PTHrP acts as an endocrine, autocrine, paracrine, and intracrine hormone. It regulates endochondral bone development by maintaining the endochondral growth plate at a constant width.
  • It also regulates epithelial-mesenchymal interactions during the formation of the mammary glands.
  • PTHrP is related in function to the "normal" parathyroid hormone. When a tumor secretes PTHrP, this can lead to hypercalcemia. As this is sometimes the first sign of the malignancy, hypercalcemia caused by PTHrP is considered a paraneoplastic phenomenon.
  • PTHR1 is responsible for most cases of humoral hypercalcemia of malignancy.

questions.text: In India, pre-transfusion routine blood screening is recommended for all diseases except:
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Dengue

  • In India, it is mandatory to test every unit of blood collected for hepatitis B, hepatitis C, HIV/AIDS, syphilis and malaria
  • If donors test positive to any of the five infections, their blood is discarded. Although the blood policy advocates disclosure of TTI status, donors are not, in practice, informed about their results

 

 

Ref: Park 27/e, p. 501

choices.text: Treatment with vancomycin and removal of catheter
Treatment with topical antibiotics at the catheter site

questions.text: A 63-year-old man is treated with chemotherapy for lung cancer He presents with fever of 38.3°C (100.9°F). He is found to have erythema at the exit site of tunneled central venous catheter in the neck, although the tunnel itself is not tender or red. Blood cultures are negative at 48 hours. His neutrophil count is 1550/μL. What is the best approach to the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Treatment with vancomycin alone

Clinicians are often faced with treatment decisions regarding potential catheter-related infections in patients who are immunocompromised from cancer and chemotherapy. Because many patients require several weeks of chemotherapy, tunneled catheters are often placed, and determining the need for catheter removal is an important consideration. When blood cultures are positive or there is evidence of infection along the track of the tunnel, catheter removal is recommended. When the erythema is limited to the exit site only, then it is not necessary to remove the catheter unless the erythema fails to respond to treatment. The recommended treatment for an exit site infection should be directed against coagulase-negative staphylococci. In the options presented, vancomycin alone is the best option for treatment.

questions.solution: Ans. B. Wuchereria bancrofti

questions.text: Match the following conditions and their presentations:
questions.solution:
Ans. C. 1-a, 2-b, 3-c

If the baby has not cried immediately after birth, baby can land up into the HIE.

questions.text:
Study the statement given below for Screening methods. False statement(s) is/are?

  1. For colorectal cancer per rectal exam is used
  2. For breast cancer if mammography is done at 40 years’ age, females it's prevalence will increase
  3. For Cervical cancer, Pap smear is used
  4. For Oral cancer by examining from outside (visual inspection) is sufficient
questions.solution:
Ans. C. 1, 4

Screening for Cancers

  • For colorectal cancer, Colonoscopy is the ideal screening test
  • For breast cancer if mammography is done at 40 years’ age, females it's prevalence will increase (Below 40 years it’s not useful due to breast tissue density)
  • For Cervical cancer, Pap smear is used (VIA is better and more cost-effective though)
  • For Oral cancer, Bimanual oral palpation is used

 

 

Ref. Park 27/e, p. 156-157

questions.text: Which of the following is likely with ascitic fluid protein 1.9 g/dL and a serum albumin ascites gradient (SAAG) of 1.4?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Alcoholic cirrhosis

A serum-ascites albumin gradient >1.1 indicates sinusoidal hypertension as the cause of ascites. The ascitic fluid protein level is a marker of the integrity of the hepatic sinusoids, which are capillarized in patients with cirrhosis and do not leak as much protein as normal sinusoids seen in cardiac causes of sinusoidal hypertension. Intrahepatic causes such as cirrhosis result in low protein levels in ascitic fluid, typically <2.5 g/dL.

Malignancy is one of the three main causes of ascites, and peritoneal malignancy results in ascites characterized by a low serum-ascites albumin gradient with high ascitic protein level.

Sinusoids are normal in cardiac ascites. Although the serum-ascites albumin gradient is elevated, the protein content of ascitic fluid is normal (> 2.5 g/dL)

Veno-occlusive disease is characterized by an increased serum-ascites albumin gradient and ascitic protein >2.5 g/dL

questions.text: A 19-year-old sex worker was treated 2 days ago for presumed gonorrhea with ceftriaxone and azithromycin. She also has a palpable spleen. Laboratory examination is notable for a Hb of 5 g/dL with normal white blood cells and platelets. Peripheral blood smear shows an excess of spherocytes. Which of the following tests will most likely confirm the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Direct antiglobulin (Coombs) test

This patient has autoimmune hemolytic anemia (AIHA) with development of warm IgG antibodies due to ceftriaxone exposure. AIHA is a serious condition; without appropriate treatment, it may have a mortality of approximately 10%. The onset is often abrupt and can be dramatic. The hemoglobin level can drop within days to as low as 4 g/dL, the massive red cell removal will produce jaundice, and sometimes the spleen is enlarged. When this triad is present, the suspicion of AIHA must be high.

questions.text: Identify the following intracytoplasmic inclusion bodies isolated from brain biopsy?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Negri bodies

Intracytoplasmic inclusion bodies:

  1. Rabies virus (Negri bodies)
  2. Vaccinia (Guarnieri bodies)
  3. Variola (Paschen bodies)
  4. Fowlpox (Bollinger bodies)
  5. Molluscum contagiosum (Henderson-Patterson bodies)

Intranuclear inclusion bodies:

Cowdry type A (Granular) à

  • Herpes simplex virus (Lipschutz bodies)
  • Varicella zoster virus
  • Yellow fever (Torres bodies)

Cowdry type B (circumscribed) à

  • Polio virus
  • Adenovirus

Intranuclear and intracytoplasmic inclusion bodies:

  • Measles virus (Warthin–Finkeldey bodies)
  • Cytomegalovirus (Owl's eye appearance)

questions.text: A 52-year-old man has undergone lung transplantation. Two months after receiving lung transplant, he developed pulmonary symptoms and was diagnosed as having bilateral diffuse interstitial pulmonary pneumonitis and bronchiolitis. Which of the following etiological agent is responsible in this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Cytomegalovirus

CMV in Immunocompromised Host:

  •  
  • AIDS patients with CD4 count < 50/µl → Chorioretinitis (MC), gastroenteritis and dementia.
  • Organ transplant recipients →
    • MC viral infection in transplant recipients.
    • Occurs between 1 to 4 months following transplantation.
    • Bilateral interstitial pneumonia in bone marrow transplant recipients.

questions.text: In vitro maturation of oocytes is a technique used in IVF pregnancies especially in women who have PCOS to prevent which complication?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome

  • In Vitro Maturation (IVM) is technique used to achieve pregnancy by aspirating antral follicles from unstimulated ovaries and culturing these immature oocytes to allow resumption and completion of meiosis in vitro.
  • In vitro maturation (IVM) may be useful in patients with PCOS in whom stimulation poses a significant risk of OHSS.

questions.text: A 34y G2 with twin pregnancy delivers in the labor room at 38 weeks. The intern who conducts the delivery is unsure about the chorionicity. The resident asks him to examine the placenta as shown. What can be confirmed about this placenta?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Two chorion, 2 amnion

  • This is a Dichorionic (2 placenta) Diamniotic (2 amniotic sacs) placenta
  • It could be either Dizygotic or Monozygotic.

questions.text: A middle aged male developed fever, weight loss, painless rubbery cervical lymphadenopathy and night sweats. He has undergone lymph node resection showing tumour cells having CD20+. Which of the following is true about this tumour?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Bcl 6 and EMA+

This is lymphocyte predominant HL where tumour cells are CD20+, BCL 6+ and EMA+.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs reversibly binds the site labelled as B in the given figure?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Ticagrelor

Ticagrelor is a reversible antagonist of P2Y12 receptors of ADP whereas clopidogrel, ticlopidine and prasugrel are irreversible antagonist of ADP.

questions.text: Most accurate investigation for local staging of Ca Prostate is:
questions.solution:
Ans. C. MRI

  • MRI with a high-tesla magnet (1.5-3 T) is the most accurate method for staging local prostate cancer.
  • Multi-parametric MRI (mpMRI) is used to evaluate pelvic lymph nodes and local stage before surgery.
  • However, mpMRI has limited sensitivity in detecting small areas of capsular spread.
  • mpMRI also plays a role in active surveillance and identifying recurrent prostate cancer after surgery.
  • Low-grade tumors may not be visible on MRI and are often not clinically significant.
  • Transrectal ultrasound (TRUS) scanning can also be used for prostate cancer staging.
  • TRUS has increased sensitivity in diagnosing locally extensive disease (T2) compared to rectal examination, but many tumors may still be missed.
  • In screening for early prostate cancer, TRUS plus rectal examination and PSA measurement detect only 30-50% of cancers, in contrast to mammography detecting 70-80% of breast cancers.

 

 

Ref. Park 27/e, p. 325

questions.text: Moynihan’s hump is an anatomical variation with respect to which of the below structures?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Right hepatic artery

The right hepatic artery can be tortuous (caterpillar turn/ Moynihan’s hump) and may lie very close to the gallbladder and the cystic duct before giving of a short cystic artery. It may be mistaken for cystic artery during dissection of Calot’s triangle in laparoscopic cholecystectomy.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman with end stage renal disease on peritoneal dialysis presents to emergency with fever, altered mental status. Peritoneal fluid is withdrawn through her catheter and sent to the laboratory for analysis. The fluid white blood cell count is 125/μL with 85% polymorphonuclear neutrophils. Which organism is most likely to be found in the culture of the peritoneal fluid?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Staphylococcus epidermidis

Peritonitis is usually a result of a failure of sterile technique during the exchange procedure. Trans-visceral infection from the bowel is much less common. Because of the high dextrose used in dialysate, there is a conducive environment for the development of bacterial infection. This can be diagnosed by the presence of >100/μL leukocytes with >50% polymorphonuclear cells on microscopy. Cloudy dialysate and abdominal pain are the most common symptoms. The most commonly isolated bacteria are skin flora such as Staphylococcus. Gram-negative organisms, fungi, and mycobacteria have also been described. Intraperitoneal vancomycin is common initial empiric therapy

questions.text: A patient with a history of Sjögren syndrome has the following laboratory findings: Sodium 139 mEq/L, chloride 112 mEq/L, bicarbonate 15 mEq/L and potassium 3.0 mEq/L. Urine studies show a pH of 6.0, sodium of 15 mEq/L, potassium of 10 mEq/L, and chloride of 12 mEq/L. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Type I Renal Tubular Acidosis

This patient has a normal anion gap metabolic acidosis (anion gap, 12). The calculated urine anion gap (Na+ + K+ – Cl–) is +3; thus, the acidosis is unlikely to be due to gastrointestinal bicarbonate loss.

In this patient, the diagnosis is type I renal tubular acidosis (RTA), or distal RTA. This is a disorder in which the distal nephron does not lower pH normally. It is associated with a urine pH >5.5, hypokalemia, and lack of bicarbonaturia.

Sjögren syndrome is one of the autoimmune diseases (along with systemic lupus erythematosus, granulomatous interstitial nephritis, IgG4-related systemic disease, and idiopathic autoimmune interstitial nephritis) that maybe associated with acute interstitial nephritis and tubular dysfunction. Sjögren-associated type I RTA may be associated with calcium phosphate stones and nephrocalcinosis.

Type II RTA, or proximal RTA, includes a pH <5.5, hypokalemia, a positive urine anion gap, bicarbonaturia, hypophosphatemia, and hypercalciuria. This condition results from defective resorption of bicarbonate

Type IV RTA is also referred to as hyperkalemic distal RTA. Hyporeninemic hypoaldosteronism is the most common cause of type IV RTA and is usually associated with diabetic nephropathy.

questions.text: A 25-year-old boy went for trekking, and came back with a rash. Weil Felix test revealed elevated OX 2 and OX 19 titers. What is the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Rickettsia rickettsiae

Weil–Felix Test

  • In epidemic and endemic typhus — ↑ OX 19 antibody
  • In tick-borne spotted fever — ↑ OX 19 and ↑ OX 2 antibodies
  • In rickettsial pox — test is negative
  • In scrub typhus — ↑ OX K antibody

questions.text: An infant is born with congenital varicella as shown below. At what gestational age did the maternal infection most likely occur?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. 16 weeks

  • Congenital Varicella Syndrome is characterized by:
    • Chorioretinitis
    • Microphthalmia
    • Cerebral cortical atrophy
    • Cicatricial skin lesions
    • Fetal growth restriction
    • Hydronephrosis
    • Limb hypoplasia
  • The highest risk of fetal infection is between 13-20 weeks

 

 

Ref: Page no. 1212-1213, Williams Obstetrics 25th edition

questions.text: A 27y G2 is in labor. She is HIV positive and is on anti-retroviral drugs since the 1st trimester. Which of the following medications used in the active management of 3rd stage of labor should be avoided in women on anti-retroviral therapy?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Methylergometrine

  • Concomitant use of ergot alkaloids and HIV protease inhibitors, delavirdine, or efavirenz is contraindicated. 
  • Efavirenz and other reverse transcriptase and protease inhibitors increase the level of methylergometrine (by inhibiting CYP34A enzyme) causing vasospasm and ischemic complications
  • Because postpartum haemorrhage due to uterine atony is often managed with methylergonovine, the Perinatal HIV Guidelines Working Group of the Public Health Service Task Force has issued recommendations concerning use of methylergonovine in women receiving certain antiretroviral agents.
