questions.text: A child with skin rash, reduced platelet count and high risk of infections should be evaluated for?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. WASP gene mutation

As it is likely case of Wiskott Aldrich syndrome.

choices.text: Available as enteric coated tablets
Acts from the luminal side of gastric parietal cells
Inactive at neutral pH
Should be taken on empty stomach

questions.text: Identify the incorrect statement regarding proton pump inhibitors?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Acts from the luminal side of gastric parietal cells

  • Omeprazole is inactive at neutral pH, but at pH < 5 it rearranges to two charged cationic forms (a sulphenic acid and a sulphenamide configurations) that react covalently with SH groups of the H+K+ATPase enzyme and inactivate it irreversibly.
  • After absorption into blood stream and subsequent diffusion into the parietal cell, it gets concentrated in the acidic pH of the canaliculi because the charged forms generated there are unable to diffuse back.
  • All PPIs are administered orally in enteric coated form to protect them from molecular transformation in the acidic gastric juice.
  •  Bioavailability of all PPIs is reduced by food; they should be taken in empty stomach, followed 1 hour later by a meal to activate the H+K+ ATPase and make it more susceptible to the PPI.

questions.text: All are non-contraceptive benefits of Combined Oral contraceptive pills (OCPs) except?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Cervical cancer

Beneficial Effects of Combined Oral Contraceptive Pills (OCPs):

  • Benign breast disorders (Fibrocystic disease, Fibroadenoma)
  • Pelvic Inflammatory Disease (PID)
  • Ectopic pregnancy
  • Iron deficiency anaemia
  • Benign ovarian disease (Ovarian cysts)
  • Malignant ovarian disease (Ovarian cancer)
  • Endometrial cancer
  • Other benefits: PCOD, endometriosis, adenomyosis, anaemia, dysmenorrhea, acne, irregular menstrual cycles, dysfunctional uterine bleeding

 

 

Ref: Park 27/e, p. 577

questions.text: A 30y primigravida delivers and following delivery of the placenta, she starts bleeding profusely. She is given oxytocin, methergine and carboprost and the following manoeuvre is done. What is the name of this manoeuvre?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Bimanual uterine compression

  • The manoeuvre shown is bimanual compression of the uterus
  • Bimanual compression of the uterus is a first-line approach to mechanical haemostasis.
  • This in itself might control bleeding significantly by assisting the uterus to use its anatomical and physiological properties such as the cross-over interlinked network of myometrial fibres for vascular compression and bleeding control.
  • It is mainly used as an intervening procedure while waiting for medical methods to act or while shifting the patient for surgical management

questions.text: Life cycle of which organism is depicted in the Image below?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Japanese encephalitis virus disease

Japanese Encephalitis (JE)

  • Causative agent: Group B arbovirus (Flavivirus)
  • Vectors of JE: Culex tritaeniorhynchus (MC), Culex vishnuii, Culex gelidus
  • Pigs are ‘Amplifier Hosts’
  • Cattle and buffaloes are ‘Mosquito attractants’
  • Ardied birds are actual hosts: pond herons, cattle egrets, poultry and ducks
  • Man is an ‘Incidental Dead end Host’

 

 

Ref. Park 27/e, p. 331

questions.text: A 46-year-old patient with multiple sclerosis for 20 years complained of stiffness in her legs. She used a wheelchair outside and a walker in the house. On examination, her legs were weak, with increased tone with passive movement. Which of the following is the most appropriate step in the treatment of this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Baclofen

Spasticity due to damage to the corticospinal tract is a common symptom in multiple sclerosis. In such patients, muscle relaxants such as baclofen are the appropriate treatment. Baclofen can be given orally or intrathecally via a baclofen pump.

questions.text: You are monitoring a term patient who had a lower segment caesarean section 4 years earlier. She is 6 cm dilated, 80% effaced and the head is at -1 station. Ten minutes ago, she was comfortable and on epidural analgesia for pain relief. Now, you note the Fetal heart rate tracing which is as shown below. You examine the patient but cannot palpate the fetal head. The maternal pulse is 90/ min; BP is 84/46 mmHg. What is the next best step?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Emergency Caesarean section

  • This is a scenario of a caesarean scar rupture
  • Emergency laparotomy/caesarean section needs to be done.

questions.text: You are applying a vacuum delivery for prolonged 2nd stage in a primigravida. The resident asks you to apply the cup on the flexion point. Which point best describes this point on the image shown?
questions.solution:
Ans. D.

  • Flexion point is a point on the fetal skull which is 3 cm anterior to the posterior fontanelle
  • It is a point where the vacuum cup is applied as traction at this point will cause flexion of the head which enables a vaginal delivery

questions.text: A new antiarrhythmic drug is found to be effective against both atrial and ventricular arrhythmias. Its effect on action potential is shown in the Figure. The effect of this new drug is most similar to?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Quinidine

  • This drug is decreasing the slope of phase 0 (Na+ channel blocking property) as well as increasing the action potential duration (K+ channel blocking property). Thus, it exhibits the properties of class Ia anti-arrhythmic agents.
  • Class Ia anti-arrhythmics include quinidine and procainamide.
  • These drugs can result in QT prolongation in ECG.

questions.text: Child Pugh Score for Chronic liver disease classified patients into three categories, namely, Category A (5-6), Category B (7-9) and Category C (10-15). This is a type of ____ variable/data now.
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Ordinal

  • Ordinal data is a categorical, statistical data type where the variables have ordered categories (like Categories A, B, C in the given question)
  • If Child Pugh Score is expressed individually as number, then it’d become Metric quantitative data.

 

 

Ref: Biostatistics by Norman, 3/e, p. 5

questions.text: A 30-year-old patient presented with features of acute meningoencephalitis in the casualty. His CSF on wet mount microscopy revealed motile unicellular microorganism. The most likely organism is?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Naegleria fowleri

Naegieria fowleri:

Mechanism of transmission à Swimming in fresh water lakes, ponds or swimming pools

Infective form à Amoeboid form trophozoid

Host à 1

Definitive host à Man

Intermediate host à Nil

Pathogenesis à Primary amoebic meningoencephalitis (PAM)

questions.text: Match the Mullerian anomaly with the most likely presenting symptom?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. 1d, 2e, 3a, 4b, 5c

  • MRKH or mullerian agenesis will present with Primary amenorrhoea
  • Transverse vaginal septum will also present with primary amenorrhoea but will have endometriosis due to the obstruction leading to hematocolpos and hematometra
  • Longitudinal vaginal septum will usually not be diagnosed until the patient presents in labor with an obstruction in the vagina
  • Septate uterus is associated with infertility and also 1st and 2nd trimester abortions, preterm labor, FGR and malpresentations
  • Bicornuate uterus commonly presents as 1st and 2nd trimester abortions although it also may present with preterm labor, FGR and malpresentations
